entry.title: Avatar Design from the Perspective of Game Social Interaction
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

 

With the rise of the metaverse, concepts such as virtual avatars and virtual social interaction have also become popular terms. In fact, avatars and virtual social interaction are not new concepts in games.

The word “avatar” comes from Sanskrit and means “a god appearing on earth in physical form.” In games, players are the “gods” who control the fate of their characters.

Thanks to the innate emotional talent of human beings, we can always easily “project” our physical and psychological conditions onto other things. The construction and identification of avatars in games are often a mapping of players’ self-awareness or desires. This strong personal characteristic is the basis for establishing social interactions and attracting others. Conversely, social interaction stems from players’ needs for emotion and belonging, and is an external manifestation of players’ higher-level psychological needs. Therefore, this mapping relationship will also have corresponding requirements for the design of the avatar. This article will explore the design possibilities of virtual avatars from the perspective of players’ psychological needs.

1. The Origin of Social Interaction: Self-Empowerment and Avatar Identification

Game social interaction stems from players’ pursuit of a sense of identity and belonging. In order to meet this demand, the primary task is to enhance players’ empowerment and identification with their avatars.

  • Self-empowerment: Believing that you have the power to control your own life.

  • Avatar identification: A psychological phenomenon in which an individual’s self-perception changes temporarily during the process of using and experiencing a game avatar, and the emotional and cognitive connection with the avatar is strengthened.

Ideal Avatar: Giving Players the Freedom of Character Customization

“An ideal avatar carries the player’s aesthetics, taste, and personal pursuits.”

Similar to social interaction in our real lives, our first impression of a person is often based on their physical characteristics, such as height, weight, skin color, hairstyle, etc., and then we further understand their identity, occupation, interests, and other aspects.

In games, how can players have the same emotional experience with virtual character images as in real social interactions, as opposed to ordinary NPCs? Sufficient identity recognition is essential. When the player’s identity characteristics are fully recognized, the player’s social window is truly opened. For example, the most basic: name, gender, identity, skills, dynamics, social relationship information, and so on.

 

Diagram: Four types of information for avatar construction and mapping

As shown in the figure above, we can divide the information that players give to virtual characters into four categories. Among them, basic information, characteristic information, and image design often give players the freedom to design themselves, encouraging players to create identity characteristics, and allowing players to gradually establish familiarity and ownership of the avatar.

In MMO games such as Revelation Mobile, the first thing players perceive is the character creation system, which allows players to immediately immerse themselves in character design.

 

Diagram: Revelation Mobile character creation interface

Character customization is also a major gameplay element, but not all players have proficient character customization skills. Many games, in order to allow players to experience more fun in character customization, will refine the operation of character customization, enrich the styles of different face shapes and makeup, and ensure that the characters created by players can satisfy themselves. Naraka: Bladepoint has hundreds of character customization materials, allowing players to create their favorite styles and shapes as they wish. Some players even have great ideas and create many funny images.

 

*Diagram: 《Naraka: Bladepoint》 Character Display.

 

Diagram: 《Naraka: Bladepoint》 Character Customization System

In addition, in the process of image design, surrounding elements such as environment and props can also be used to present personal interests and tastes, which not only enhances the personal attributes of the player’s character, but also provides a basis for the extensibility of design and the sustainability of social interaction in the game.

 

*Diagram: 《Naraka: Bladepoint》 Character Display Surrounding Elements.

 

Diagram: 《Revelation Mobile》 Character Display Surrounding Elements

Blank Avatar: Giving Players the Freedom of Character Imagination

“Simple images make it easy for players to project their identities.”

Unlike ideal avatars, blank avatars prefer relatively symbolic characters. American cartoonist Scott McCloud put forward an interesting point in his book “Understanding Comics”: the fewer details a character has, the more likely the reader is to project himself into that character. When players combine a symbolic character with a meticulously described world, they can generate a strong sense of immersion.

In Sky: Children of the Light, the player’s avatar often appears in a minimalist form. The game enhances the player’s sense of immersion through the design of the environment and sound. The blank space of imagination and the atmosphere rendering of the environment—this strong contrast enhances the player’s self-empowerment and identification with the avatar, ignoring the difference between the “avatar character” and themselves.

 

Diagram: Game “Sky: Children of the Light”

2. The Process of Social Interaction: Self-Presentation and Group Identification

Frontstage Self-Presentation

“Frontstage” refers to the part of an individual’s performance that regularly defines the situation for the observer in a general and fixed way. The frontstage is where the avatar is concentrated, and it is the self-presentation where self-characteristics match character characteristics.

Players can present themselves through interactive designs in the game, enrich the character characteristics of the avatar, and attract the attention and recognition of other players.

Avatar Interaction Design

  • Daily interaction: Give the avatar character traits.

The interactive design and script design of the avatar itself, such as sound, dialogue, and actions, are important elements that help players achieve self-presentation during group interactions. In addition, real-time interactions such as text, likes, comments, voice, emoticons, and gifts can help players enrich their own character settings during social interactions, and enhance the fun and richness of social interactions.

The chat system of Revelation Mobile is similar to social software in real life. Players can use personalized chat methods and display their personality in real time through text, emoticons, voice and other chat tools, making the personality image of the avatar more vivid and three-dimensional. In addition, designs such as colored text and text shortcuts in the game make this chat tool more playable.

 

  • Interest interaction: Show personal hobbies and specialties

In Revelation Mobile, the player’s voice and various music-based gameplays are distinctive features that run throughout the game. This kind of interest interaction fully demonstrates the player’s self-characteristics and integrates personal characteristics into the role, and also provides the possibility of expanding social scenarios. For example, the tea room is designed based on the players’ common interest in music. In addition to exploring the love of music, traditional culture, painting hobbies, etc. can also be integrated into the game to strengthen the interactive design of the avatar.

 

Diagram: Music social interaction in “Revelation Mobile”

  • Action interaction: Cultivate avatar behavior habits

Encouraging players to use the avatar’s actions to develop behavioral habits is also an important factor in the interaction between players. In Final Fantasy XIV, there are many tasks that require players to use emotional actions on NPCs, such as encouraging, comforting, and touching NPCs. This process will continue to strengthen the player’s positive emotions. Since there are many such tasks, players will naturally get used to putting commonly used emotional actions on the shortcut bar. In this way, the threshold for interacting with other players is also very low. After everyone finishes the dungeon and meets acquaintances in the wild, they will easily make a gesture to say hello, which is much more convenient than typing in the chat box.

 

Diagram: Task interface of “Final Fantasy XIV”

  • Emotional interaction: Enhance the emotional characteristics of the avatar

In Sky: Children of the Light, players help each other to present themselves step by step through cognition and emotional progression, and gradually deepen their connection with each other. For example, by lighting the candles of other players’ avatars, they will change from small gray people to a state with a special decoration—this is the first step in interacting with people; further, players can also give nicknames to other players to deepen their memory of each other, and so on.

 

Diagram: Avatar images in different social states in “Sky: Children of the Light”

Group Interaction and Group Identification

Group identification is the process of classifying people or things, emphasizing common destiny, common goals, common emotions, and the interdependence of group members. The construction of group identification is mainly completed in the process of intra-group and inter-group interactions.

The essence of game social interaction is to achieve the goal of group interaction and group identification through joint participation. In games, ultra-temporal connections provide a situational basis for players to participate together, without considering the distance of reality. Players generate emotions due to their common love, making members naturally form a psychological feeling of “being together” or “being one of us”. Group interaction and group identification require effective social scenarios, and different social scenarios and experiences will also have different requirements for the design of avatars.

  • Avatar identity design

In games, social scenarios are created for players through task design, challenge design, reward design, and intimate interaction design.

In these group gameplays, in order to facilitate group interaction, more member identity designs and corresponding character assignments are needed, and there should be differentiated gameplay when players join the group. This can be achieved through daily gameplay. When a player joins a group, the administrator should immediately set an identity for him and inform him of the corresponding tasks he needs to do immediately. In this way, differentiation can be expanded through subdivision, the player’s interest chain can be built, and a reasonable scene for social interaction can be created. Games such as Identity V, Werewolf, and LARP (Live Action Role Playing) fully mobilize the players’ subjective initiative with such character identity settings. In some battle scenarios, the matching methods of top lane, middle lane, bottom lane, jungle, and support also strengthen the players’ interest chain and promote the division of labor and cooperation among players.

 

Diagram: Character profiles in “Identity V”

  • Avatar relationship setting

The interpersonal pattern of closeness and distance is called the “differential order pattern”. Like ripples spreading on the water surface, it extends from oneself, circle by circle, and divides closeness and distance according to the distance, as shown in the figure below.

 

In the group interaction of the game, the relationship setting between avatars can expand more social scenarios. For example, the common relationship settings such as master and apprentice, husband and wife, and gang can trigger different gameplays. Through this relationship setting and gameplay design, players are stimulated to communicate and collaborate with strangers, creating emotional bonds. Players can experience the ambiguity and warmth with the opposite sex in the game, and the communication and cooperation between teams or other groups, so as to achieve the social goals of group interaction and group identification. The gameplay of companionship, bonding, marriage, master-apprentice, grudge, and sect in Revelation applies this relationship setting method.

 

Diagram: Master-apprentice list in “Revelation Mobile”

  • Avatar display design

Putting personal business cards (equipment, titles, achievements, battle records, clearance progress, collection progress, etc.) in the display system is conducive to gaining the attention and recognition of others, satisfying the players’ desire to show off, and plays an important role in the establishment of social relationships. Designs such as likes, sending flowers, worship, and the display of top-ranked player models can not only increase the display effect, but also enhance the interaction between players.

Both Naraka: Bladepoint and Revelation have leaderboard display designs, which can increase users’ group attention and help and encourage users to obtain group identification. In Revelation, when players team up, they can also click on the character card to view detailed information and perform dynamic interactions such as “send gifts” and “step on”. Obtaining the attention of other players through the avatar display system is also one of the ways to gain a sense of identity.

 

*Diagram: Leaderboard display of players in “Naraka: Bladepoint”.

 

*Diagram: Personal display when players team up in “Revelation Mobile”.

 

Diagram: Dynamic display of players in “Revelation Mobile”

3. Inspiration from the Metaverse for Avatar Design

The popular metaverse social interaction not only has the shadow of virtual social interaction, but also has the characteristics of physical social interaction. It uses technologies such as AR, VR, and XR to build a holographic virtual reality platform. The interaction between us and our friends is no longer just simple voice, text, pictures, and videos. We can also go shopping, watch concerts, and play games together. Everyone does not have to worry about time and space, but enjoy an immersive experience.

With the metaverse empowering the game industry, the terminal devices that carry games will also be iterated, and the game industry may enter an era of wearable devices with VR/AR and other technologies as the core. The concept of the metaverse has spawned a large number of VR/AR technology implementations. Users can enter virtual reality scenes by wearing VR helmets, AR glasses and other devices to achieve an immersive experience.

The high picture quality and strong physical interaction of VR scenes give more space for the design of virtual avatars. The 3Dization of the image, the smoothness of the action, the closer correspondence between the avatar and the real world, and even the multiple experiences of vision, hearing, and touch have more possibilities.

In addition, the creation of virtual identities allows players to be deeply bonded with the game through digital assets, helping the game achieve breakthroughs in user retention. Matthew Ball, former head of strategy at Amazon Studios, said that identity, as one of the eight characteristics of the metaverse, can be regarded as an evolved version of the online identity in current games, and can represent players in a more creative and realistic way through avatars and other methods. In the metaverse game world, the importance of in-game identity and customization options is increasingly prominent. Players will have permanent digital identities and personalized virtual images. Through social activities in the game with virtual identities, they can obtain matching digital assets or custom assets, such as virtual land, houses, works of art, and pets, to achieve an immersive experience similar to the real world.

The self-expression of virtual identity is not only the continuous expansion of personalized images. With the rise of the emerging concept of self-sovereign identity (SSI), people will interact in the digital world with the same freedom and trust capabilities as in the real world. The avatar is no longer just a mapping of self-awareness, but is more likely to become one of the roles in real life.

entry.title: Is Falling in Love with Paper People Just a Daydream The Immersive Experience of Dating Sims
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

 

With the expansion of the female gaming market, female-oriented dating sims have also become a battleground for major manufacturers. However, judging from the data, although there are many newly launched female-oriented dating mobile games, their market performance has declined very quickly. Taking five female-oriented mobile games of the two-dimensional and mixed styles launched in 2021 as an example, compared with the first month’s revenue, the revenue in March 2022 decreased by an average of 85%. It can be seen that not all games have truly touched female players. To provide players with an immersive dating experience and break through the homogenization of the category, it is inseparable from the research on the psychology of female players in dating games.

1. The Psychological Mechanism Behind the Immersive Experience

The main reason why dating games are so popular with players is that they create a highly immersive virtual world for players, where players are psychologically satisfied and unconsciously bring their fantasies and emotions from real life into the virtual game.

Ideal Self

In reality, we always have some dissatisfaction with ourselves. Sometimes we wish we could be more charming and successfully pursue the person we like; sometimes we wish we could be braver and say no to a black-hearted boss. The game world gives us such an opportunity to become our ideal self: you can become a popular figure in school, or you can firmly engage in the career you love.

For example, in the dating game Starry☆Sky, released in Japan years ago, the heroine Tsukiko Yahisa is set as the only girl in the school and serves as the secretary of the student council, and is sought after by many people. This slightly “Mary Sue” setting, although very different from real life, satisfies the player’s fantasy to a certain extent: good looks, loved by those around her, and also has the beautiful qualities of bravery and independence.

 

Similar settings are also very common in domestic female-oriented dating games. In For All Time, the heroine is an excellent cartoonist who accidentally travels to the world of her own comics and adventures with familiar characters. During the game, the player obtains a new identity (cartoonist, etc.), and also develops a deeper understanding and identification with this identity as the story progresses.

 

From a psychological point of view, self-identity is formed by the interaction between the individual and the real world. However, in dating games, players can easily switch between real life and the virtual world to improve their self-identity. At the same time, the identity experience given to players by the virtual world is often far from the real self, but closer to the ideal self. Players can find a shadow of themselves in the game, and they long to be this character and accomplish many things that cannot be done in real life. In terms of appearance, the characters in the game have ideal figures and beautiful faces; in terms of personality, the fantasy plot like a novel, and the character’s strength and independence in the face of difficulties, are all their projections of the ideal self, satisfying the player’s need for self-worth realization.

Deep-Seated Motivation

Strong emotional experience is an important reason for immersion. Browsing the Weibo comments of dating games, we can always see players loudly confessing, “Please marry me quickly, don’t make me beg you on my knees”, “Husband, how can I live without you”, this kind of emotional experience is actually strongly related to the player’s game motivation.

 

After conducting a questionnaire survey of 612 female-oriented game players and semi-structured interviews with 15 players, researchers found that for positive emotions, external motivation (game sound, picture, plot, color) has a greater impact than internal motivation (social interaction, entertainment, learning, etc.). Both motivations have a significant positive correlation with positive emotions. The stronger the motivation, the more obvious the player’s positive emotional experience of the game. In contrast, for negative emotions, the stronger the external motivation, the lower the negative emotions; the stronger the internal motivation, the higher the negative emotions.

Specifically, if we see a player on the forum who is angry, anxious, and frustrated because of a female-oriented game, she is more likely to be an intrinsically motivated player who prefers to gain knowledge, relieve stress, make friends, and enjoy the pleasure of completing achievements through the game. And if it is a player who feels happy and satisfied in the game, then he may be driven by both internal and external motivations. He not only likes to gain knowledge and relieve stress through the game, but also appreciates the game’s graphics, art, music and other designs.

 

Therefore, it is also worth paying attention to by industry professionals to better awaken players’ motivation to play during the operation stage.

Flow Theory

Psychologist Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi defines flow as a feeling of total engagement in an activity. Flow is often accompanied by high excitement and fulfillment. Activities that produce a flow state often have the following characteristics:

  1. Activities we tend to engage in
  2. Activities we will focus on
  3. Activities with clear goals
  4. Activities with immediate feedback
  5. We have a sense of control over this activity
  6. Our worries disappear when engaging in the activity
  7. Subjective sense of time changes - for example, you can engage in a long time without feeling the passage of tim.

 

In dating games, players often feel the passage of time without noticing it because they appreciate the handsome cards and charming voices of NPCs. This state is the flow state in psychology.

Therefore, understanding the conditions for the generation of the flow state, designing the game accordingly, and enabling players to achieve the flow state in the game is also an important step in creating an immersive experience.

2. How Do Female-Oriented Dating Games Build an Immersive Experience?

So, after understanding the player’s psychological mechanism, how should game developers build this immersive experience?

Focus on Player Self-Worth

Aggregate and analyze big data before game production, and put game settings that meet the psychological needs of modern women into the game, for example, players can independently choose “dating objects” and will also have a unique identity to realize self-worth. During the game, players invisibly feel the cultural content it contains - women’s freedom of marriage, economic independence, etc.

Such female-oriented games act as disseminators of feminist culture, returning the feminist ideas obtained from big data analysis to the target users, forming a cultural dissemination.

 

Awaken Player Motivation

In terms of awakening external motivation, excellent graphics and well-known voice acting teams are great bonuses. In addition, female-oriented games can focus more on male NPCs in the setting of scenes. Even if there are scenes where the heroine appears, the heroine is also popularized from the characteristics, so that more players can substitute themselves. This type of game also does its best to create this first-person perspective in the text, and rarely personalizes the heroine. Even in some games, the heroine has different personalities when facing different male NPCs.

Such an “unconscious” shaping of female characters makes the same plot a unique personal “experience” for the player, that is, through the different psychological experiences of the player, the game becomes personalized and customized.

 

In addition to awakening external motivation, designers can also start from awakening internal motivation to make female users feel “empathy”. For example, in For All Time, players can interact with NPCs using virtual messages. In addition, sending emojis, making phone calls, dating, and other behaviors add a strong “sense of reality” to the player.

 

Create a Flow State

For players to truly enjoy the game, they need to fully substitute themselves into the game characters and participate in the game. When they are fully immersed in it, they will temporarily forget the current time and space and enter the world presented by the game, that is, reach a flow state. In dating games, some clever designs can also help create a flow experience:

In terms of goal setting, improve the player’s clarity of goals and control over the game. For example, the illustration system can help players clearly understand what their goals are and how many achievements they have achieved now. Ungained card sets can also prompt players what else they can do to better achieve their goals and improve their sense of control over the game.

In terms of emotional design, dialogue and voice acting are used to assist in the shaping of characters and the experience of the plot. For example, voice acting is not only reflected in the dialogue in the plot, but also used in various aspects of the player experience, such as the New Year greetings on the login interface, the statements around the birthday theme on the event interface, etc., incorporating emotions into the peripheral systems, making the immersive experience more integrated.

 

3. Summary

In general, there are still infinite possibilities for the research on the immersion of female-oriented games: VR technology makes lovers within reach; the metaverse completely connects the real world and the online world; high technology may allow players to truly embrace “paper people” in the future. Gradually upgrading the immersive experience is also the common expectation of players and designers.

entry.title: May We All Be Blessed With Longevity, And Share The Beauty of the Moon Though Thousands of Miles Apart The Happy Ending in Games
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

 

It’s the Mid-Autumn Festival again, one of China’s four traditional festivals, and it also represents reunion. Throughout history, people have often used the “waxing and waning of the moon” to contrast “joys and sorrows, partings and reunions.” Su Shi’s “Prelude to Water Melody” uses the line “May we all be blessed with longevity, and share the beauty of the moon though thousands of miles apart” to give the Mid-Autumn Festival a unique romance and the theme of expecting reunion. Even today, the main folk activities of the Mid-Autumn Festival still revolve around the theme of “reunion.” What does a happy ending look like in games? And why do players always crave a happy ending?

1. Happy Ending (HE) or Bad Ending (BE)?

When we browse Weibo (Chinese Twitter), we can always see many trending topics about popular dramas, usually in the format of “#XXX reveals that the ending of XX is HE#.” The ending of every popular film and television work triggers huge discussions, and it seems that the audience’s demand for HE (Happy Ending) is becoming stronger and stronger. When “Love Between Fairy and Devil” was broadcast, many fans were very concerned about whether “Dongfang Qingcang” and “Little Orchid” could have an HE, and they were relieved only after seeing the two together in the finale.

Although the terms HE and BE that we see now often appear in film and television dramas, these abbreviations actually originated from the gaming circle, especially in AVG games with multiple endings and multiple branches. However, many 3A masterpieces now also provide different plot choices. For example, in Cyberpunk 2077, different feedback from each dialogue of the protagonist will open different branch plots, which in turn will affect different endings. Of course, interactive movie games are more typical. For example, in Detroit: Become Human, the ending of the story depends entirely on the player’s choices, and there are countless branch plots in the middle. It is difficult for players to repeatedly play the same ending, which also dilutes the concept of HE and BE. Now it is difficult to define the different endings of a game with the traditional binary opposition definition, just like “Tian Long Ba Bu” (Demi-Gods and Semi-Devils), where “everyone is wronged, and all who are affectionate are sinful.” The labels of HE/BE are now difficult to use to summarize the ending of a game.

 

AVG games are still sought after by many players

In the more ancient and once-popular text adventure games, HE and BE were still hot topics that players would always pay attention to. Even in addition to HE and BE, text adventure game enthusiasts would also discuss TE (True End) and NE (Normal End), but at present, these two labels are obviously only applicable to the game field. TE is the so-called “true ending,” which is a real ending that players believe is superior to other endings. It often requires players to complete all other endings before they have the opportunity to unlock TE, and other endings will automatically “degenerate” to NE.

As an extension of text, in the field of online literature, HB/BE even directly form a label-based screening process. If it is BE, there will be a “risk warning” before reading. Of course, readers can also filter it out in advance, so that they can read it clearly.

2. What are the Happy Endings in Games?

Returning to the topic of games, although multiple endings have now become the choice of many games, most mainstream games still have linear plots, and it is not difficult to list the happy endings in games.

The plot of It Takes Two is not complicated. It roughly goes: “In the game, the little girl hears that her parents have decided to divorce, and she is heartbroken and prays to Dr. Hakim that they will not separate. With the help of the doctor and his guidance, the souls of the parents are transferred to two dolls, and they reluctantly begin an adventure in the magical world, trying to return to their original bodies. The two experience various hardships and dangers together, and after taking four lessons from Dr. Hakim, they gradually find their original sincere feelings and decide not to separate. So the spell is broken, and the family of three lives happily ever after..

 

Mending a broken mirror is the biggest theme of the plot of “It Takes Two”

Another masterpiece ported to PC, Days Gone, tells a story in the apocalypse. Facing the zombie siege, the protagonist and his brother and girlfriend, the three of them flee together. The girlfriend and brother are seriously injured, and the rescue helicopter that is about to take off cannot carry three people. In the end, the protagonist and his brother choose to stay, and the girlfriend successfully boards the rescue helicopter.

After the two escaped, they found the medical camp where the helicopter landed, but found that it had already been looted by zombies. Although they did not find the girlfriend’s body, the protagonist desperately believed that she had passed away, and felt self-blame and regret for it. Until one day, he accidentally discovered the possibility of his girlfriend’s miraculous survival, and then drove north, going through all kinds of hardships, and finally reunited with his girlfriend.

 

*The protagonist is very sure that his girlfriend is dead and has erected a monument for her.

 

The protagonist reunites with his girlfriend at the end

The reason for giving examples of these two games, in addition to their happy endings, is another characteristic, that is, they have all experienced the plot of “loss and recovery,” experiencing ups and downs, rather than being smooth from beginning to end. Such a plot setting often gives players a more gratifying feeling and releases more positive signals.

A psychological counseling supervisor once mentioned that when members of a mutual aid group shared their experiences of loss and recovery, some positive signals were often released along with them. For example, a member found a wallet that had been lost a long time ago in an unexpected place before participating in the group activity, so he suddenly said during the sharing that he felt he had the energy to clean up the house, and everything was developing in a good direction. This is a phenomenon of synchronicity in analytical psychology. When something happens internally, the external world also presents similar signals to us in some way.

3. Why Do Players Also Want a Happy Ending?

In fact, the title reveals everything. “May we all be blessed with longevity, and share the beauty of the moon though thousands of miles apart” is preceded by “People have joys and sorrows, partings and reunions; the moon waxes and wanes, is bright or dim: these things have always been this way since time immemorial (人有悲欢离合，月有阴晴圆缺，此事古难全 - rén yǒu bēi huān lí hé, yuè yǒu yīn qíng yuán quē, cǐ shì gǔ nán quán)”. Games, like movies, are immersive experiences. Players will put themselves into the role and have empathy.

You can try to recall the Spring Festival of 2020. The COVID-19 pandemic spread rapidly in an unimaginable way, and you and I around you, and even the entire society, experienced a huge psychological shock. Seeing various negative emotions on the Internet, many people will have a feeling of discomfort, which we call “empathic exhaustion.”

An excellent game can create a traversal game space with high degrees of freedom and more options, providing players with a very in-depth interactive experience from the structure and mechanism. But what really attracts players to continue playing is the story that integrates traversal selection and interactive narrative techniques, as well as the story content that players personally participate in telling. In the immersive plot of about 10-20 hours, we experience everything that the game characters experience. If we are really allowed to repeatedly lose one partner after another, and repeat one BE after another, we will be in a state of intense mental fatigue: once we start to walk into the pain of others, it is difficult to stop continuing to feel the pain, and it is also difficult to get out of it.

 

The author’s mental state was also affected by empathy when experiencing “Hellblade: Senua’s Sacrifice”

From a social perspective, in fact, many people in real life are engaged in “professional helping” industries, such as doctors, psychological counselors, etc. They often need to undergo very professional related training before they can be licensed to work. For example, psychological counselors need to follow supervisors to handle a large number of cases, and colleagues also need to discuss regularly with each other to avoid empathic exhaustion caused by trying to establish emotional connections with patients. And with the deepening of medical training, in many cases, their ability to empathize with patients will decrease, and even empathy钝化 (dùnhuà, blunting) will occur. Research also shows that compared with practitioners in the music, science, and finance industries, professional helpers are more likely to have substance abuse problems, which means… they also collapse.

But players will not undergo any professional training. In The Last of Us Part II, Abby’s use of a golf club to torture and kill Joel made many players feel quite uncomfortable. In the previous work, players spent a lot of time feeling and believing in two pitiful people who lost their families. Even if there is no blood relationship between the two, they can support each other like a real father and daughter, fighting against the entire wasteland world. But in the sequel, Joel is brutally killed, and even many people are unbelievable when they play this plot. Unlike the general film and television drama bridges where the protagonist is shot or falls off a cliff and there is still a chance, Joel, who was hit multiple times on the head with a golf club, is completely offline and cannot be saved. Many players also said that no matter which perspective they substitute, this ending is ultimately difficult to accept.

After a huge disaster, we can easily distinguish who are firefighters and police officers from the crowd - because they are the only ones who rush to the scene when everyone else is staying away from the disaster scene. But as players of ordinary characters, we just want to stay away from the traumatic experience scene.

 

The duo in Part 1 experienced life and death in Part 2

So, rather than saying why we want to see a happy ending, it’s better to say that players don’t want to see others suffering during a long period of immersion. To put it simply, players don’t want to be sad, players don’t want to be upset. Social psychology has learned a beautiful world expectation, which roughly means that in order to give the whole world a sense of meaning, people tend to believe that the world is beautiful. That being the case, why embrace a miserable world?

entry.title: Capturing the Myriad Thoughts of Players - Designing with Emotion
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

 

Video games are called interactive art. Players need to integrate themselves into the game world to savor the scenes created by the developers and the stories they write. However, it is not easy to allow players to smoothly solve the puzzles set by the developers without them realizing that they are being restricted by the game’s guidance.

To achieve this, it is first necessary to clarify “what kind of experience” you want to give the players. Only by guiding the direction with this can you accurately create or combine mechanisms that better express the essence of the work. However, “gameplay”, “mechanisms”, and “systems” all these game elements will eventually be mapped to the player’s emotional experience, which is why game experience design starts with emotional experience.

People may forget what someone said, but they will never forget how someone made them feel. Therefore, mobilizing emotions will naturally make people remember that feeling. This is the importance of emotional experience, as the saying goes, “sentimentality” is human nature.

 

Speaking of this, I’m sure everyone will have doubts: then why don’t players choose the smooth and linear enjoyment of movies, but instead spend energy to challenge and even be a little self-abusive in games? This is precisely because games can bring players unique emotional experiences: a sense of choice, freedom, responsibility, and achievement, etc. These experiences are difficult to obtain through movies or other means.

1. Emotions Give Rise to Feelings

Before discussing how to influence players’ emotional experience through design, we need to distinguish between two concepts: emotion and feeling.

  • Emotion: It is the short-term, instinctive, and impulsive feeling that the player produces. For example, sudden scares in horror games, the surprise of getting a good draw in gacha games, etc.
  • Feeling: It is a social, advanced, delicate, and lasting feeling, which is a summary and sublimation based on emotions. For example, you will cry because of the departure of a character in the game, and you will be shocked by the ending of the game for a long time.

From the perspective of individual psychological development, emotions appear earlier, while feelings appear later. Emotions are situational and temporary; feelings are profound and stable. After understanding the concepts of the two, we find that changes in players’ emotions can influence and give rise to different feelings, thereby affecting subsequent experiences and feelings. So how to make reasonable use of players’ emotions has become an important part of emotional experience design.

2. Factors Affecting Players’ Emotions

The process in which you perceive various influencing factors in the game and trigger emotional fermentation in your heart is the emotional experience, and this process is also constantly affected by “interaction”. The main factors that affect players’ emotions in the game include the following aspects.

Interaction Frequency

Generally speaking, the higher the frequency of interaction, the more intense the player’s emotions. For example, in a shooting game, players need to simultaneously hold down the keyboard to adjust the position, move the mouse to control the direction, and click the mouse to aim and shoot. The interaction frequency required in the game is very high, and the player’s emotions are prone to be in a more excited and nervous state.

 

In some puzzle games, it is often necessary to reduce the interaction frequency so that players can switch from tense emotions to relaxed emotions that are conducive to thinking, and reduce the interference and interruption of players’ thoughts with less present interaction methods.

Interaction Feedback

Interaction feedback refers to the perceptual feedback that players instantly obtain after performing interactive operations. Feedback is an important part of the interaction process. Only when players receive obvious and sufficient multi-dimensional feedback will they think that the current interaction is meaningful, and the emotions triggered by the interaction will be more real. Conversely, if you don’t want players to perform a certain interactive behavior, just don’t give them any feedback. For example, in a shooting game, if the designer does not allow players to harm their teammates, players will not receive any feedback when they hit their teammates in battle.

Real-time Performance

Real-time performance refers to the visual, auditory, tactile, and other information that players obtain in real time during the game, regardless of whether they interact or not. They can all bring various emotional experiences to players in the game.

  • In visual performance, different colors (red feels passionate, blue feels calm), different shapes (circles feel gentle, spikes feel dangerous), different shots (looking up feels oppressive, shaking feels uneasy), etc. will make players have different emotions.

  • In auditory performance, different rhythms, instruments, pitches, etc. will also bring different emotions to players.

  • In tactile performance, the maximum level of tactile performance we can achieve so far is the delicate multi-level vibration of the game controller.

 

3. How to Use Emotions to Design Game Experience?

Emotional fluctuations in the game are the most important reason why players can remember and recall this game, so designers need to make clever designs using this.

Create Short-term Emotional Stimulation

To mobilize players’ tension in competitive and action games, a moment is usually created - in this moment, players must complete complex operations accurately and without error to win. For example, dodging and parrying when players fight bosses in the God of War series; players in Dota reverse the situation and win the victory through perfect cooperation with teammates. In these moments, the player’s tension is constantly stimulated, and the emotions are pulled to the highest point and then released like a floodgate at the moment of victory. This pleasure of emotional release is “addictive”.

 

《God of War》 QTE moment

 

《DOTA2》 Teamfight Comeback

Tension can be used, and other emotions can also be used. For example, in Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2, under the guidance of the plot, players, as members of Task Force 141, fight side by side with their teammates in order to complete the mission of their trusted superior, Shepherd. The repeated battles side by side deepen the friendship between the players and their teammates. In the conversations and work with the teammates, players will recognize the unique personality of each teammate, which deepens the players’ cognitive depth of the NPCs.

But in the later missions, the commander of Task Force 141, Shepherd, betrayed them and mercilessly killed or indirectly harmed the team members. All these changes will make players feel shocked, unbelievable, angry, sad, and broken down. The hatred for Commander Shepherd is high.

 

Task Force 141 in “Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2”

 

The classic scene in “Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 2” where “Ghost” and “Roach” go through hardships to complete the mission and break out of the siege, but are betrayed by the long-trusted superior.

 

The unfortunate “Ghost” and “Roach” are thrown into a pit and burned together.

It is this plot that makes players remember the character “Ghost” who is not the protagonist. Even today, six years later, there are still a large number of players who feel sorry for the character “Ghost”, and its related peripheral products are in short supply.

Drive Emotions with Choices

The above examples all use the simple and strong stimulation of players to generate rapid emotional fluctuations. However, sometimes we want some practices that are slower to take effect but have a longer-lasting impact. At this time, we can try to impact the players’ self-awareness to generate emotional fluctuations. There is a theory in psychology called self-discrepancy theory, which divides everyone’s cognition of themselves into three parts:

  • Actual self: Objective and true evaluation of oneself
  • Ought self: Feeling that you should do those things, this is your obligation (such as calling 119 when you see a fire)
  • Ideal self: What you would do in your ideal self (such as doing charity)

When there is a gap between the actual self and the ought self, you will feel that you have not fulfilled your responsibilities and obligations, and then you will have emotions such as guilt and shame. The most classic example is the “moral dilemma”. Taking The Witcher 3 as an example, in the game, facing a woman who is heartbroken by the loss of her child, orphans who are suffering from hunger and cold, innocent villagers, and a wealthy but childless baron, no matter how the player chooses, they cannot save everyone. At this time, the player will inevitably feel the gap between the actual self and the ought self, and then generate the above emotions.

 

The classic Bloody Baron quest in “The Witcher 3”

Another classic case is This War of Mine. There is no difficulty option in this game. The difficulty of clearing the game is more based on the player’s code of conduct. Players can choose the human mode: take in every defector, help everyone who asks for help, don’t take a needle or thread from the masses… But the consequence of this is often to increase the difficulty of clearing the game, and eventually end in tragedy.

 

The lack of supplies throughout the game forces players to choose “violent” methods to solve problems. When players choose to abandon moral constraints and have the mentality of “it’s just a game” and “the game must be cleared”, the game also becomes “easy”. So you break into the mansion of the old couple and loot their supplies, because you are about to run out of food; you start to sneak attack other survivors in the ruins and take their weapons and bullets, because you need weapons to protect yourself; you will decisively abandon the injured companion, because the soldiers next door are about to find this place; you will keep the child who came to ask for medicine out of the door, because only these supplies are left. But in fact, making these decisions is not easy.

 

In the face of such complex emotions, it is often difficult for people to make decisions. The reason why it is difficult is because people’s emotions are deeply touched and they experience the difficulty of choice. Therefore, designing complex emotional experiences, grasping the complex emotional factors in people’s hearts, and creating a difficult situation are very important in game design.

On the other hand, when there is a gap between the actual self and the ideal self, people tend to have emotions such as frustration and disappointment towards themselves. These emotions are usually not strong, because people often fail to reach their ideal self. After these emotions often appear, they will also begin to become numb.

So is the gap between the actual self and the ideal self not able to be used to generate strong emotions? Of course not, because conversely, once this gap is crossed and the ideal self is reached, people will feel great joy, satisfaction, and pride. These powerful and very positive emotions will also be addictive. “The bigger the gap crossed, the greater the emotional fluctuation”.

Sublimate Experience with Emotion

So now the question is how to create this huge gap?

Self-sacrifice is a good way. Regarding self-sacrifice, the writer Somerset Maugham has a wonderful description in The Razor’s Edge: “Self-sacrifice is an overwhelming emotion. Even lust and hunger are insignificant compared to it. It makes people make the highest evaluation of their personality and drives people to destruction. It can be worthwhile, or it can be worthless. No wine is so intoxicating, no love is so destructive, and no sin is so irresistible. When sacrificing oneself, one instantly becomes greater than God.”

The most amazing game that incorporates “self-sacrifice” and allows players to complete the leap of the ideal self is Nier: Automata. In the ending of Nier: Automata, the task difficulty of the player fighting the production team is designed to be very large. But when the player is about to be shot down, they will see messages from all players in the world, encouraging you to persevere.

 

Then, you find that your plane is protected by 6 wingmen. Each plane is a player’s save file. Being shot down means that the save file is lost. In this process, you will feel the kindness from all over the world. So many players are willing to sacrifice their save files just to block a bullet for a stranger.

 

After clearing the game, the game also gives players the opportunity to sacrifice themselves, but it is not a simple and direct option. This design is particularly clever. First, it allows players to leave messages, just like they were encouraged before, to encourage other players who are in a hard battle, immediately allowing players to complete the role transition from the helped to the helper. Then step by step, through a series of questions, the meaning of the player’s self-sacrifice is enhanced.

“Are you going to save the weak?” “Are you sure you want to use all your data to save someone you don’t know?” “That person may be someone you hate, are you still willing to do this?” “The chapters and functions you have worked so hard to unlock will also be unavailable, are you still willing to do this?” “In fact, you may not be thanked for doing this, you may be seen as hypocritical, are you still willing to do this?” Every time the player clicks [Yes], they reach an ideal self.

 

This ending always controls the player’s emotions, appropriately uses the player’s “self-sacrifice” emotions, makes the player feel “participating in a great cause”, and thus generates a high evaluation of their own morality, reaching the “ideal self” in their heart, and completely deepening the experience of the game.

4. Summary

Designers create a real game world through various methods. The purpose of various gameplay, systems, and level settings is also to allow players to better immerse themselves in it, satisfy players’ various fantasies in real society, play the role of a hero to kill dragons, and play the role of a knight to save the world. Everything is to allow players to feel the beauty of the virtual world, gradually gain self-identification, emotional catharsis, and communication and resonance with others in the process of experiencing the game.

entry.title: Clocking In In The Virtual World Game Check-In System Experience Design
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

 

When it comes to checking in, you must be familiar with it. From reporting to school as a child to clocking in at work now, checking in has been integrated into all aspects of our lives. In games, we can often see this delightful and worrying check-in design.

We hope to get corresponding rewards through check-ins, but too many check-ins will make us feel bored. And check-ins do have a magical attraction for us. To exaggerate, as long as the “check-in” function is added, we will unconsciously check in to receive rewards. Nowadays, the “addictive” effect of check-ins has also prompted more games and mobile applications to add this function to their products.

 

Check-in Page in the Game

In game products, check-in means that the player has logged in to the game or participated in a certain activity. It refers to the player’s operation on the game interface at a specific time and conveys to the system that the product has been used. This method improves the user activity and retention rate of the game to a certain extent.

Nowadays, check-in activities have basically become a standard gameplay in every game, especially check-ins during special events or festivals, which play an important role in maintaining high player activity during the event. It is precisely because the check-in system in the game has a strong attraction to players, allowing players to obtain certain rewards after checking in, that makes players dependent on and “addicted” to check-ins.

Although check-ins will also bring an uncomfortable sense of restraint to some players, this sense of restraint is generally replaced by the pleasure of various rewards. Even if some players still cannot accept this method, it is undeniable that the design of the check-in function does have great appeal to players, while maintaining a high level of player activity in the game for a certain period of time, and even attracting some fans who are keen on checking in.

1. Why Design a Check-in Function in Games?

Game Perspective

For game products, the design of the check-in function mainly serves to increase player activity, improve retention, attract new users, and promote revenue.

  • Boost Activity: Through the check-in function, the game allows players to log in to the game every day, increasing player activity in the game.
  • Retention: The check-in function allows players to form a habit of playing the game through this form, encouraging players to go online and receive rewards as much as possible.
  • Attract New Users: Attracting new users means that players can share socially through check-in tasks, so that the number of players can be increased to a certain extent.
  • Promote Revenue: Promoting revenue is to guide players to transform from non-paying players to paying players by differentiating rewards.

Player Perspective

From the player’s perspective, the main purpose of players checking in is to obtain certain rewards. According to Maslow’s hierarchy of needs, rewards are mainly divided into material and spiritual rewards.

First, players can get material rewards: that is, players can get game points, prizes, skins, props and a series of rewards that attract them to log in through check-ins. Second, players can get spiritual rewards: that is, the rewards obtained by players through check-ins make them emotionally satisfied (the need to be praised and recognized by others), and self-actualization (such as game rankings, achievement completion, obtaining medals, etc.).

Therefore, regardless of whether it is from the game perspective or the player perspective, the check-in design meets the needs of both parties. It can not only meet the deep needs of players for material and spiritual rewards, but also bring high attention, activity and retention rates to the game. Therefore, the importance of designing check-in functions in products is self-evident.

2. Why Does the Game Check-in Design Capture the Hearts of Players?

After understanding what check-in is and why we should design check-in, we need to discuss why check-in design is so “magical” and makes players fall into the cycle of check-ins. We believe that two points are very important.

Check-in Becomes a Super Symbol

As mentioned at the beginning of the article, check-in has been integrated into all aspects of our lives. It can be said that check-in has become a “super symbol” implanted in our brains. This forms that as long as it is any check-in design, players will unconsciously click to check in. Because they already have expectations for check-in in their minds, check-in will always have an attraction effect on players.

Psychological Suggestion of Check-in

Check-in behavior is generally considered to be continuous, so after players start checking in, they will tend to complete it continuously. And players have a clear understanding of check-in. If they complete the check-in, they will get rewards. If they continue to complete the check-in, they will get more rewards. This psychological suggestion will drive players to actively complete the check-in. The check-in function first deeply attracts players at the psychological level, and then through different check-in designs in the game, players are driven to complete the check-in by psychological inertia.

 

3. How to Design a Check-in Function that Players Will Love?

Since check-in is so attractive to players, how should the check-in in the game be designed? In order to allow players to continue checking in for a long time and stay in the game, the “addiction” model can be incorporated.

The “addiction model” mainly includes four links: trigger, action, reward, and investment. Through the reward mechanism, it stimulates users to repeatedly start the game, cultivates players’ behavior habits, and makes players dependent on and惯性(guàn xìng - inertia) to the game; at the same time, the characteristic function design further improves the activity and retention of existing players in the game, allowing the check-in function to achieve a win-win situation for the game and players.

Trigger Design - Player Guidance

The game check-in has a guiding effect on players. When guiding players, it is necessary to use triggers to drive players to enter the “addiction” cycle of check-in in the game. Triggers can prompt players to take action and give them psychological hints before the player’s check-in behavior begins.

In the game, it is necessary to establish a more obvious check-in prompt to get the player’s attention and increase the exposure of check-in in the game. The commonly used prompt methods in the game are pop-up windows and non-modal reminders of icons. In Naraka: Bladepoint, when players enter the game, a modal activity window will pop up to remind players of recent activities and activity check-ins. After entering the game, the icons on the right use bright light flashing to highlight the activities and check-in entrance.

 

《Naraka: Bladepoint》 Activity Entrance

At the same time, on the left side of the game lobby, task guidance is used to allow players to view the tasks that can be completed every day and obtain corresponding rewards. The setting of simple tasks not only guides players to familiarize themselves with the gameplay, modes, etc. of the game, but also becomes an important auxiliary function for players to experience the game. At the same time, reducing the difficulty of tasks and the amount of stimulation for players, reducing the burden on players, encouraging players to experience the game, and obtaining corresponding rewards after completing tasks, all make the trigger effective and allow players to enter the next link of the “addiction” model.

 

《Naraka: Bladepoint》 Daily Tasks and Activity Center Icons

Behavior Design - Emotional Goals

  • Increase player motivation

A very important goal of check-in design is to influence player emotions and design player behavior. In the check-in process, it is necessary to provide players with a goal, so that players have expectations in their hearts, and hope that they can complete the goal at a certain stage. When players get closer and closer to this goal in the process, their actions will occur faster.

This effect of accelerating player actions through behavior design will have an impact on player emotions. When the player’s current goal is achieved, their motivation will be restored. Therefore, when the player completes the current stage goal, it is necessary to continue to set the next goal to stimulate the player’s emotional goal. In My Dear Farm, players can get a box of furniture by completing 7 days of check-in. In order to get special prizes, players will insist on checking in, and the closer they are to the gift package, the rewards will gradually increase, thereby further increasing player motivation.

 

《My Dear Farm》 Check-in Interface

  • Reduce the player’s check-in cost

Another aspect of influencing player emotional goals is to reduce the player’s check-in cost. That is, when players face a large amount of information and choices, they will need more time to think, which will greatly increase the player’s burden and then reduce player emotions. Therefore, in the game, breaking down large goals into small goals that are achieved in stages will reduce the burden on players, increase players’ goal expectations, and enhance players’ phased sense of satisfaction.

For example, in Knives Out, the game divides the days of each month into a target cycle of 7 days (i.e., one week). Players will receive gold chips as a reward for accumulating 7 check-ins. In order to obtain this reward and exchange items in the game, everyone will insist on checking in, and the closer they are to the 7-day gift package, the better the gift rewards will be. This effectively stimulates the player’s interest, enhances their check-in motivation, and makes the probability of players breaking their check-in streak lower and lower.

 

《Knives Out》 Check-in Page

Reward Design - Strengthen Behavior

Players obtain certain rewards through check-ins, which can enhance their check-in motivation. At the same time, the feedback of obtaining rewards reinforces this behavior. Check-in provides players with a new way to obtain game resources. Players only need to maintain loyalty to the game and perform simple check-in operations to obtain corresponding game resources. Of course, the design of rewards should also consider the gradual progress of the process, and it is necessary to meet the different needs of players according to different cycles.

For example, Naraka: Bladepoint‘s anniversary celebration interspersed different levels of rewards during the check-in period, fully mobilizing players’ emotions and making them unable to stop once they started checking in. At the same time, they can obtain advanced costumes for new characters during the check-in to guide and strengthen their willingness to experience new characters, and meet the needs of new and old players through other rewards. Even in some games, a complete set of equipment will be broken down into check-in rewards, so that players can continue to complete check-ins to collect the equipment. This method can also stimulate players’ collection needs.

 

《Naraka: Bladepoint》 Anniversary Event Check-in Page

Investment Design - Emotional Resonance

As the last link of the “addiction” model, the investment design makes players develop a habit for the game by generating emotional resonance with players. The more players invest in the game, the more they will value check-in. The game can start with investment design and mobilize players’ emotions. As the number of check-ins increases, the number of days players have checked in is displayed, and even a personalized check-in commemorative booklet can be customized for players, so that players have a different kind of emotion for the game.

For example, in A Dream of Jianghu, when a player reaches 666 days of check-in, the game thoughtfully prepares a personalized commemorative booklet for the player, visually displaying the player’s investment in the game. This design brings satisfaction and emotional resonance to the player’s emotional experience, and also makes the player unforgettable about the game.

 

《A Dream of Jianghu》 Personalized Commemorative Booklet

Characteristic Design - Theme Presentation

In addition to the “addiction” model, attention should also be paid to the characteristic design of check-in. Common check-in activities are designed with regular check-in boards, but long-term presentation in this way will always give people a feeling of fatigue of looking at a calendar, which will cause players to have the burden of completing tasks. Therefore, breaking the conventional design can not only bring players a novel experience, but also highlight the theme of the game or the theme of new activities.

For example, in the game Onmyoji, the design of its check-in interface is presented in the form of daily divination check-in, which is very consistent with the tonality of the game. The way of divination check-in also gives players a novel experience, driving players to unknowingly complete the check-in behavior during the divination process.

 

《Onmyoji: The Card Game》 Check-in Page

In the check-in interface of a certain period of activity in Identity V, players can check in by wiping the mirror, and they will also receive corresponding rewards after completing the check-in. In addition to the personalized design of the interface in combination with the game theme, the way of checking in by wiping the mirror is also very novel. At the same time, players will find that every time they wipe the mirror, the tasks in the mirror will change slightly, which hints at the development of the plot and makes players imaginative.

 

《Identity V》 Event Check-in Page

4. Conclusion

In summary, if the check-in design wants to further attract players, make players develop the habit of logging in to the game every day, and complete the corresponding activity check-ins in the game to obtain rewards, it is necessary to guide players through trigger design, satisfy players’ emotional goals through behavior design, strengthen player behavior through reward design, and arouse player emotional resonance through investment design. And present novel themes with characteristic designs to improve event data.

Although too many check-in designs will make some players feel bored, a good check-in design will definitely not make players feel burdened. As long as the check-in design is integrated with the game and presented in various forms, everything can be used for check-in. If it can make players think of the game unconsciously and develop the habit of opening the game unconsciously, it should be a check-in that players will never forget and love, and it is also a great game that amazes players!

entry.title: Seeing is Not Necessarily Believing Optical Illusion Games
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

 

The famous printmaker M.C. Escher’s painting “Waterfall” depicts a building that can make a water wheel run forever by relying on a “circulating waterfall.” At first glance, the viewer will feel that the waterfall in the painting is flowing, but upon closer inspection, it will be found that the waterfall in the picture will flow down continuously, but the falling water will flow upstream. This is an optical illusion picture that can be reasonably depicted in two-dimensional space, but cannot actually appear in three-dimensional space.

 

Optical illusions make the viewer’s visual experience contradict normal reasoning, breaking the stereotype of human binary thinking and allowing the viewer’s imagination to break through the boundaries of natural physical laws. In recent years, optical illusion games have captured many players with their unique visual illusions and endless imagination.

In this article, we will mainly introduce three types of visual illusions: impossible spaces, perspective illusions, and Gestalt illusions, and analyze the reasons why optical illusion games attract players.

1. Impossible Spaces

The formation of impossible space utilizes the conversion and alternation of viewpoints, showing three-dimensional forms on a two-dimensional plane, but presenting ambiguous visual effects in the three-dimensional form, causing confusion in space.

The Penrose triangle is a typical impossible figure based on impossible space. It looks like a cube, composed of three cuboids with rectangular cross-sections. The three cuboids form a triangle, but the angle between two cuboids seems to be a right angle. The above properties can be drawn in a two-dimensional plane, but cannot be realized on any normal three-dimensional object. The painting “Waterfall” is precisely through the splicing of two Penrose triangles, making players have the illusion that the waterfall is flowing.

 

The game Monument Valley uses a large number of Penrose triangles as the game screen. The protagonist, IDA, shuttles through the impossible graphic space. Players only need to move or rotate the pillars in a certain order to reconstruct a feasible space and achieve the conditions for safe passage. As shown below, in this level, players need to overcome the three-dimensional illusion generated in the two-dimensional plane, help the protagonist of the game pass through the Penrose triangle corridor and reach another door.

 

In addition, the well-known Möbius strip is also an optical illusion phenomenon based on impossible space. A Möbius strip is a paper strip formed by twisting a piece of paper 180 degrees and then gluing the two ends together. If an ant is placed on this ring, it can walk from the front to the back without crossing the boundary, and keep going, giving the viewer an illusion of infinite loop. Although the Möbius strip exists in the three-dimensional world, it only has the characteristics of two-dimensional space. It has only one single-sided surface, rather than two sides in three-dimensional space.

 

The buildings in the game Monument Valley also draw on the Möbius strip. The protagonist IDA can change from standing vertically to standing horizontally through the twisted corridor, that is, gravity has changed, which is an impossible picture in three-dimensional real life.

 

2. Perspective Illusions

Perspective means that two objects of the same size appear larger when they are closer to the person and smaller when they are farther away. Generally, parallel projection is used in games. In parallel projection, even if the distance of the object changes, the size of the image will not change; but in perspective projection, the distance will affect the size of the image. As shown below, these are two yellow lines of the same length, but the human brain will judge its size according to the environment in which the object is located, and think that the yellow line in the distance is longer.

 

Superliminal uses the relationship between perspective depth and reference objects as the two core elements of the game. Players must change their perspective and think unconventionally in order to wake up from their dreams. As a basic gameplay, players need to pick up specific props in the environment, change the reference objects, and use the most direct perspective relationship to enlarge or reduce objects, so as to adjust specific props to the appropriate size and achieve the conditions for passing the level. For example, players can use the depth relationship between the cheese and the corridor to enlarge the cheese slice and make it a slope to jump over the hole in the ground.

 

In the puzzle adventure game Perspective, perspective illusion is the main way to solve puzzles and explore the game world. Players can rotate the camera angle and use visual errors to create visual distance changes between platforms that are originally far apart, creating a path that does not exist to achieve the conditions for passing the level.

 

3. Gestalt Illusions

When people’s visual center focuses on a complex figure, the human brain will judge the object in front of it according to the familiar shapes or contours stored in memory. After obtaining relevant prompts, people’s visual experience will automatically complete the rest of the incomplete contours in the image. This is what is called Gestalt illusion in psychology. For example, in the figure below, the viewer seems to be able to automatically see a white triangle that does not actually exist.

 

In Monument Valley‘s “Ida’s RED Dream: AIDS charity special edition”, the third level uses the art of Gestalt visual illusion. This is a castle that cannot exist in the real world. Each light gray corridor can be completed by rotating the dark blue building. Players can rely on previous visual experience to automatically connect the corridors. In the game, once the light and shadow are unified, it means that a new path has appeared.

 

In the game Gorogoa, the game screen is divided into four parts, and each area will present a scene for players to explore. Players can zoom in on objects in the picture and find clues that can be spliced or embedded with other scenes, so that the originally static picture will become an animation. This game cleverly uses the Gestalt illusion suspense formed by perceptual prediction and integrates it into the traditional jigsaw puzzle game rules.

 

4. Why Do Optical Illusion Games Attract Players?

Why can optical illusion games attract players with these wonderful visual phenomena? We have mainly summarized the following three aspects.

Increase the Interaction Between Players and the Game Scene

When the game character moves in the game space, it generally faces a fixed, preset picture. The perspective centered on the picture rather than the player’s control can better present the picture content, and it is also an optimized design that can smoothly advance the plot development, but it can also be critically considered as a manifestation of technological dehumanization.

Video games are places that pursue interactivity, and creators are constantly looking for ways to break the restrictions that bind players’ hands and feet. Optical illusion elements provide this possibility for game creators. In optical illusion games, players are no longer bystanders of the game screen. By manipulating the game perspective, players can actively change certain elements in the game scene. Players enhance their sense of immersion and substitution through interaction with the game scene.

Break Through Conventional Thinking and Find the Connection Between Different Game Scenes

In the game Moncage, players need to explore by interacting with objects in different worlds, and use visual errors to find a perfect angle to splice certain objects in the two worlds. The process of finding connections in different worlds in the game is not a blind trial and error, but players use their unique observation and imagination to break through the dimensions of time and space to find connections and unlock new spaces one by one.

The core gameplay of optical illusion games is to change perspectives and use visual differences to find the connections between different scenes, which requires players to break through conventional thinking and explore the true connections between the visual illusions presented in the game screen from different angles. Players can also gain a strong sense of satisfaction after exploring and completing the level.

The Dual Pleasure of Aesthetics and Puzzle Solving

The pictures of optical illusion games are constructed from unique geometric figures and comfortable colors, and are supplemented by beautiful music to give players a beautiful sensory enjoyment. Through the combination of audio-visual elements, players can understand the artistic conception and gameplay of the optical illusion space as a whole, and discover and complete task plots during the interaction process to obtain psychological satisfaction. Players can get the dual pleasure of aesthetics and puzzle solving throughout the game process.

5. Conclusion

This article introduces the main optical illusion phenomena, including: impossible spaces, perspective, and Gestalt illusions. The ingenious design of optical illusions can allow players to experience a visual feast that violates the laws of physics and the pleasure of exploration and puzzle solving. In the game, players need to use their own unique thinking, change perspectives, and use visual differences to combine seemingly unrelated scenes. Incorporating optical illusion elements into action, adventure, role-playing and other games to increase the fun gameplay may also allow players to gain a wonderful experience.

entry.title: The Use of Inclusive Language in Games and Their Localization
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

 
“Words have power, words are power, words could be your power.” — Mohammed Qahtani

In the process of games going global, we often rely on two types of text to communicate directly with players: one is in-game text; the other is communication within the community. These two types of discourse need to fully express the game maker’s game concept, creative ideas, and in-depth thinking, to avoid causing unintended discrimination and prejudice among players.

The game market research agency Newzoo once launched a player sentiment study on more than 1,500 people and released a report saying that diversity, fairness, and inclusion are becoming increasingly important in games. Many players do not necessarily feel a sense of belonging in the game or feel welcome in the game community, and these current situations are closely related to the use of inclusive language. This article will introduce inclusive language and its use in the game localization process.

1. Why Use “Inclusive Language” in the Localization Process?

Inclusive language aims to avoid “expressions that express or imply ideas that are sexist, racist, or otherwise biased, prejudiced, or denigrating to any particular group of people.”

Inclusive language is based on the principles of equity, diversity, and inclusion (EDI principles). It strives to avoid expressing or implying prejudice against any particular group of people, especially marginalized and vulnerable groups, and does not contain any content that may imply that a person is superior to another because of age, gender, race, ethnicity, culture, sexual orientation, disability, or health status.

When we serve players from different backgrounds and of different types, of course, the producers do not want to form an opposition with a certain group because of this unnecessary or unintended language offense, which will have a bad impact on the game.
