For example, in the research on the temperament preferences of adult female fashion in China, fairy and sexy are ranked at the top, while in the research on the temperament preferences of adult female fashion in Japan, gentleness is ranked at the top. This is also relatively close to the personality expectations of adult women in different social environments.

3. Summary

Immersion is experiencing the story, substitution is personal experience, and viewing is observing the story. The relationship between different involvement methods and fashion is: In blank slate character games, players who substitute and players who view need to be treated differently. Players who substitute are more suitable for designing theme role-playing fashion, and viewers pay more attention to the beauty and universal aesthetics of fashion. The same is the immersive way of involvement. The theme gives fashion highly recognizable characters and attractive plots. For example, collaborating with other themes outside the game can give fashion a deeper meaning and purchase attraction.

entry.title: Motivation + Ability + Prompt - How Does the Fogg Model Guide Player Behavior
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

 

1. What is the Fogg Behavior Model?

The Fogg Behavior Model was proposed by Dr. BJ Fogg, founder of the Behavior Design Lab at Stanford University. The Fogg Behavior Model states that three elements must converge simultaneously for a behavior to occur: Motivation, Ability, and Prompt. When a behavior does not occur, at least one of these three elements is missing.

  • Motivation: The degree of desire to perform a certain behavior.
  • Ability: The ease or difficulty of completing a certain behavior.
  • Prompt: The incentives and feedback that trigger a certain behavior.

This can be explained in a diagram.

 

The essence of interaction design is the design of user behavior. The Fogg Model, as a classic user psychology model, can be said to be one of the underlying logics of interaction design and has important guiding significance for interaction design.

The Fogg Behavior Model (FBM) makes it easier to understand behavior in general. It highlights three main elements, each with subcomponents. Specifically, the FBM outlines the core motivators (motivation), simplicity factors (ability), and types of prompts. The subcomponents define the larger elements; for example, in the FBM, the word ability refers to how simplicity factors work together in the context of prompts.

 

Motivation

Unlike psychologists who advocate for extrinsic and intrinsic motivation, Professor Fogg divides the sources of motivation into three types:

  • Sensation (physical level): Essentially, sensation is driven by our pursuit of pleasure and avoidance of pain. Some behaviors bring us pain (behaviors we want to avoid), some behaviors bring us pleasure (behaviors that motivate us to continue), and sometimes multiple motivations conflict with each other, leading to our mental anguish (such as wanting to lose weight but also wanting to eat high-calorie foods).
  • Anticipation (emotional level): The benefits that can be obtained or the punishments that can be avoided by taking action (which can correspond to extrinsic motivation in psychology). For example, hope and fear are the most powerful motivators, making people yearn to be part of something very meaningful.
  • Belonging (social level): This makes people feel that they are part of society, and this sense of belonging keeps them motivated. For example, all your friends are doing it (which corresponds to extrinsic motivation in psychology).

However, motivation itself is constantly changing and very unstable. Therefore, in specific design, we can prioritize solving ability and prompt issues to improve the behavior conversion rate of motivated users. Secondly, we should seize the peak of user motivation to guide users to perform corresponding behaviors, rather than converting after the user’s motivation drops. When motivation is high, people can do difficult things, but once motivation declines, people will only complete easy things.

Ability/Cost

The horizontal axis of the Fogg Model is ability, from “hard to do” to “easy to do.” Professor Fogg believes that people have a natural tendency to be lazy. Therefore, although people can be trained to perform target behaviors, it is usually more effective to make the behavior easy. In addition, he believes that what users care about most is cost. Instead of increasing his motivation to do something with more temptation, it is better to think about reducing the cost of doing it.

 

In games, the player’s ability is reflected in the hero level, the player’s moves and abilities in the game, the amount of currency and items they have, and so on.

Prompt

The hardest thing in the world is “doing the right thing at the right time.” For promoting conversion, it is “persuading users to do what they can with the right motivation at the right time..

 

  • Spark: When users do not have enough motivation, they need to be stimulated with explanatory text or videos to generate motivation, such as limited-time free items, discounts, and novice prizes for new users in the store.
  • Facilitator: When users already have enough motivation, but sometimes they don’t know how to do it, they need help to complete the conversion.
  • Signal: When users have both the motivation to do it and know how to do it, what they need is a reminder at the right time.

Successful conversion occurs when motivation is strong and implementation costs are low, which is above the threshold in the figure above. But sometimes, strong motivation and low cost cannot be fully satisfied. At this time, it is necessary to ensure that there is no design with high cost and insufficient user motivation.

2. How Does the Fogg Model Guide Player Behavior?

Motivation - Increase Players’ Motivation to Play Games Through Incentives and Rewards

  • Increase player motivation - Reward distribution

Providing a reward preview in the task interface allows players to know the specific rewards they can obtain by completing the task, thereby increasing players’ motivation to complete the task. Players often complete tasks they didn’t originally intend to do because they want specific rewards.

At the same time, since the motivation and ability required to stimulate player behavior are two complementary factors, when setting awards, it is also necessary to set the size of the reward according to the difficulty of the task. When a task is difficult, setting a reward of sufficiently high value can motivate players to take action.

 

《Naraka: Bladepoint》 Tiered Season Rewards

  • Provide external motivation

The most common external motivations in games are various medals, rewards, and leaderboards. These rewards are not only a reward for players’ activity in the game, but also an external motivation to encourage players to improve their abilities and continue to be active in the game, prompting players to obtain these badges out of the mentality of “I want what others have..

 

《Naraka: Bladepoint》 Hero Badges

Just like shopping in daily life, when we see something that many people buy, we always can’t help but take a second look, and our desire to consume is higher. In the design of the store page, highlighting hot-selling products is also a way to increase players’ sense of belonging and stimulate consumption.

 

《Destiny 2》 “Hot” Label

Increase the scarcity of goods - things are more valuable when they are rare. People always focus on what they will lose, not what they will get. When we see a limited-time discount in our shopping cart, we usually feel a sense of urgency that we are about to lose the opportunity to pick up a bargain. This mentality is also used in some game stores, using a combination of discounts and limited-time sales to stimulate player consumption.

 

《PUBG》 My Exclusive Store Limited-Time Discount Sale

Ability - Increase Players’ Ability to Perform Behaviors and Reduce the Difficulty of Execution

  • Reduce the difficulty of behavior by breaking down tasks

“By focusing on Simplicity of the target behavior you increase Ability.” Simplifying the target behavior is the process of empowering users.

Breaking down tasks into steps and guiding players to complete them is a common way to guide players to complete tasks step by step. In novice tasks, it is also common to gradually break down the tasks to guide players to accumulate experience. By turning some high-cost behaviors, such as completing tasks with larger goals, into small steps, and supplemented by different completion incentives, users can unknowingly accumulate a lot of successful experience.

 

《Naraka: Bladepoint》 Gradually Breaking Down Tasks and Rewards

  • Increase players’ ability to complete tasks

When players first enter a game, there is usually a novice guidance process to help players quickly understand the gameplay of the game and improve players’ abilities in the game. Whether the novice guidance can truly enable players to master the operation methods and gameplay of the game is also an important factor that determines whether players can stay in the game in the future.

Prompt - Give Players Prompts

Inform players of game updates, daily operations, and other in-game activities at an appropriate time to increase player activity and participation.

  • Small details to guide players to new information in the game - red dot prompts

Red dot prompts are a basic guiding method widely used in interaction design. For example, the various new message prompts in the apps we see most often in our lives use a small red dot to prompt users to open the message box to view messages, which also applies users’ obsessive-compulsive disorder psychology to a certain extent.

When a new costume is added to a hero, the red dot prompts at all levels of the path can ensure that players can accurately find the newly launched costume among the many pieces of information, thereby prompting players to try it on and purchase it. Including game updates, in-game event updates, and gameplay opening prompts, etc., can also be used in this simple way to guide players to participate in new activities in the game.

 

《Naraka: Bladepoint》 Red Dot Prompt Guide for New Events

 

《APEX》 Red Dot Prompt Guide

Limited-time open gameplay prompt - Naraka: Bladepoint‘s “Realm of Gods” gameplay is open for a limited time, but players may not accurately remember the opening time of the gameplay. A small red dot can remind players that the gameplay is open and it’s time to start a game. Without the prompt of a small red dot, players may gradually forget that this gameplay will be opened at a specific time. In this function, such a design not only guides players’ behavior, but also reduces players’ cognitive load. They no longer need to remember the opening time of the gameplay themselves.

 

《Naraka: Bladepoint》 Realm of Gods Gameplay Open Prompt

  • Make players more confident about the difficulty of the level - inform players of their abilities through UI differences

In the “Realm of Gods” gameplay of Naraka: Bladepoint, the UI difference of the recommended Divine Sense level above the level confirmation button visually informs players whether they have matched the behavioral ability required by the level. The gold color of recommended Divine Sense Level, indicates that the player has reached the recommended Divine Sense level, informing players that has the ability to perform this action, thus directly satisfying the “ability” factor that triggers the action. When the required behavioral ability is not reached, a red prompt is used to prevent players from misjudging their abilities and challenging the level, but instead gaining frustration from it.

 

Realm of Gods - When the player meets the recommended level for the level

 

Realm of Gods - When the player’s level does not reach the recommended level

3. Conclusion

By deconstructing the Fogg Model theory behind the most basic interaction design, we can understand the three elements that affect user behavior: motivation, ability, and prompt (triggering element), helping us to design players’ trajectories in the game more purposefully during the design process, and to verify whether a design can well guide players’ behavior in design self-checks, thereby improving players’ gaming experience and motivating them to continue to be active in the game.

entry.title: Invariance Amidst Change - Commonalities and Individualities in Game Top Navigation Design
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

 

In games, the top navigation is the skeleton of the game, supporting the overall content and information, helping the game to display the entrances of various functions intuitively and clearly to the player. The design of the top navigation is invariant amidst change. Its form serves its navigational functionality and follows similar interaction principles. This article will start from the functionality of the game top navigation, use multiple cases to illustrate the design commonalities of the game top navigation, and talk about its adaptation design on different platforms.

1. Form Serves Function - Commonalities of Top Navigation

The form of design serves the function. The function of top navigation boils down to displaying entrances of different levels and playing a certain guiding role. A good top navigation design should be able to clearly express the information of each entrance, and provide appropriate and eye-catching guidance for the information that needs attention.

Design Basis: Design According to Browsing Order

Users have an “F-shaped” browsing mode when browsing web pages or apps. The characteristic of this mode is to focus the user’s attention on the top and left side of the page. Specifically, the first line of text on the same page receives more attention than the following lines; the first few words on the left of each line are more acceptable than the words on the right.

In design, the functions of the top navigation bar will also be arranged according to weight, and more important functions will be placed in the left area. Because in the structure of the “F-shaped mode”, the content on the far left in the top navigation has more visual weight, it is located in a more main visual area and has a higher priority. For example, in the mail system of Naraka: Bladepoint below, the main title is placed on the far left, and the other entrances are arranged according to the frequency of use and general browsing habits.

 

Design Hierarchy: Clearly Defined Information Presentation

The top navigation belongs to the global control layer of the interface, and undertakes the control and navigation functions of the entire product, determining the interaction logic and sequence of the product. The top navigation supports the overall structure as the skeleton of the product, which can effectively reduce the understanding cost of the interface.

Therefore, the level of the top navigation itself also needs to be more distinct, and it needs to be able to simplify the information of the main interface and help players quickly reach the target interface. If the top navigation occupies an important position and presents too much information, it will increase the burden of use. In the design process, it is necessary to sort out the functions by level, and incorporate the important entrances and information of high frequency into the top navigation.

Taking the design of the lobby entrance of Naraka: Bladepoint as an example, important content related to the in-game experience (heroes, talents, weapons), and the main promotion information related to the season are placed on the left side of the top navigation, and the less important information and functions are placed on the right side, achieving a relatively distinct level display.

 

《Naraka: Bladepoint》

Functional Entrance: Concise and Clear Entrance Design

  • State

    • Unselected state: Concise and clear, progressive

      Text is often used to describe the function of the entrance. If the interface information density is too high, icons can also be used to reduce the cognitive load caused by text. In addition, when there is secondary navigation, it is necessary to design in terms of level layout, color, text, etc., to distinguish the primary and secondary relationship of different levels of navigation.

       

- **Selected state:** Distinctly different, prominent state

   The entrance in the selected state will be distinguished by adding a colored background block. Some text information is hidden in the secondary tab, and the selected state will also display the corresponding text description.

      


- **Hover state:** Supplementary explanation, click prompt

    In some interfaces with too much information, you can consider using the Hover state to trigger explanatory Tips to explain the detailed role of the entrance, so that players who want to further understand a certain function or state can achieve cognitive purposes with additional text information.

      


    ---

    *《Civilization VI》*

    ---

    In games, for text function entrances that do not have a strong sense of click, the Hover state can inform the user that it is operable.

      


- **Unopened state:** Clear expression, weakened design

    Some entrances need to meet certain conditions before they can be opened, so it is necessary to design an unopened state, which is often expressed by icons and different colors.

      


    When the player clicks on the unopened entrance, it is necessary to give the player feedback to inform them of the unlocking conditions.

      


    ---

    *《RIDE 4》*

    ---

  • Key Prompts

    • Red dot prompt: Key prominent, prompt clear

      In games, a “red dot” will be designed at the function entrance to prompt players to check for new changes. The red dot can also change with the state when selected. In Ghost Recon Breakpoint, the selected red dot will expand into a text description.

       

    ---

    *《Ghost Recon Breakpoint》*

    ---

- **Special styles:** Based on function, changing performance

    In the navigation, you can also try to design special reminders based on the nature of different functions. For example, in *Call of Duty: Modern Warfare*, commercial functions such as season passes and stores have designed different styles of red dots.

      


    ---

    *《Call of Duty: Modern Warfare》*

    ---

2. Adapting for the Platform - Individuality of Top Navigation

Consoles, computers, and mobile phones are the three main carriers of games. Due to the differences in their interaction methods, users have different experience habits, which also brings different design focuses.

The operation and display areas of consoles and PCs are separated, so the button prompts and icons on the interface can be made very small, and the arrangement position is also less restricted, and there is no need to worry about blocking or accidental touches during operation. The problems that need to be considered in device adaptation for these two types of carriers are simpler, and there are more free design choices.

PC: Design that Breaks Through Limitations

The biggest advantage of PC games is the mouse. Because the mouse has a hover state, it can directly break through the level, making the display area the interactive space. The interface can bear a huge amount of information and interaction without causing large-scale occlusion. At the same time, the operation accuracy is very high, and the volume of interactive components can be compressed as much as possible, which virtually increases the information capacity of the display area. Compared with the icon-based mobile game function entrance design, the top navigation can use the “text + color block background” entrance presentation method without considering the volume problem.

 

In some cases, the mouse may be occupied by other functions and the cursor is not displayed. At this time, the PC can also configure key bindings for the top navigation and display them on the UI.

 

Console: Design Within Level Constraints

Console games are generally interacted with through a controller. Because this type does not use a convenient cursor, the interface pays special attention to levels, and multiple interactions are required to achieve the goal. Many operations (including click/slide) of controller games will have corresponding button prompts to deal with various risks during the operation.

Similar to PC, placing the navigation at the top is more in line with the player’s browsing movement and controller key layout, and it is also used more frequently in console games. The top navigation keys are generally configured on the shoulder buttons (L1, R1 or LB, RB), and the corresponding button UI can be drawn in the game to remind players of the operation method.

 

《Naraka: Bladepoint》

 

《Animal Crossing: New Horizons》

Some games with double-layer tabs will configure the first-level tabs on the shoulder buttons, which have a relatively short key travel and clear pressing feedback. The secondary tab is configured on the right joystick to facilitate switching with the tab content.

 

《The Legend of Zelda: Breath of the Wild》

In addition, the design of Naraka: Bladepoint is supplemented by the operation mode of “left joystick + A button”, and a mouse-like operation method is designed. The joystick becomes a mouse, providing players with more convenient choices.

 

《Naraka: Bladepoint》 PS5 Version

Consoles benefit from their natural carrier advantages, and players have a greater sense of ceremony when playing. The creation of immersion in games on this platform is particularly important, and it is necessary to pay attention to visual, auditory and other aspects of the experience, and the design of sound effects is also more detailed. For example, in Forza Horizon 5, when switching left and right with the controller, the left and right channels will be distinguished. This subtle design can also highlight the quality and delicacy of the game.

 

《Forza Horizon 5》 Xbox Version

Mobile: Inconvenience and Limitations of Top Navigation

Due to the limitations of screen size and operation mode, mobile games can be described as “every inch of land is gold” in design. Due to interaction method restrictions, areas where top navigation would generally be placed are outside of operational range, most games would opt for bottom navigation. The top is used to present high-frequency information, for ease of player perusal.

Taking Ace Racer as an example, the lobby interface adopts a bottom-level navigation design, placing high-frequency entrances and the start game button at the bottom right, and displaying information such as currency that needs to be viewed frequently but does not require operation at the top.

 

《Ace Racer》

3. Conclusion

Game top navigation is a very common functional design, serving its function of filtering and classifying information and displaying entrances. A good top navigation design can greatly reduce the player’s information load and optimize the game operation and cognitive experience. In the development process, designers should design different operation methods according to the characteristics of different terminals, and adjust the design details to achieve the best interactive effect.

entry.title: How to Successfully Conduct a Field Study in Thailand Before Launching a Game Overseas
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

 

The Southeast Asian game market has always been a must-go place for many manufacturers when expanding overseas, with huge potential. It has also been called the fastest-growing region for the global game market by Newzoo. According to Statista, the total size of the game market in the region was US$5.24 billion in 2022, and is expected to grow to US$6.28 billion by 2024 and US$7.47 billion by 2027.

Southeast Asia has 11 countries, a total population of 650 million, and 380 million Internet users, with an Internet penetration rate of 58%, and this proportion will continue to increase; mobile devices are becoming cheaper and more powerful for Southeast Asian consumers, which also contributes to the fact that more than two-thirds (67%) of the game industry’s revenue in the region comes from mobile devices, while the proportion of PCs is only 24%, and consoles only account for 9%.

Clearly, Southeast Asia is a mobile-first market. As the country with the second-largest GDP in Southeast Asia, Thailand’s 32 million gamers have helped the Thai game market generate more than 6.8 billion RMB in revenue, making it one of the most notable game markets in Southeast Asia.

As one of the most important countries for domestic games to expand overseas in Southeast Asia, the Thai mobile market has unlimited possibilities. And a full understanding of local users will be a very important factor affecting the success of overseas expansion in this country. Recently, for a game under development, we went to Bangkok, the largest city in Thailand, and two border cities in Thailand, Ubon Ratchathani and Chiang Mai, to conduct in-depth research.

1. Popular Game Genres in Thailand

Before setting off, we collected some data to understand the currently popular games in Thailand. Combined with past research experience, we initially came to the following hypothesis: Thai players like to play games developed by their own country, and in terms of game types, they prefer multiplayer competitive games, especially MOBA, battle royale, MMORPG, and casual games, which have the best revenue in Thailand.

Take the top ten of the iOS best-selling list on April 2, 2023 (from Qimai Data) as an example, including 4 casual games, 1 MOBA game, 2 sports games, 1 MMORPG, and 1 shooting game.

 

Free Fire, published by Garena, one of the largest publishers in Thailand, is very popular; in addition, football mobile games are also very popular in Thailand. eFootball 2023 has long occupied the top three of the best-selling list in Thailand, and often competes for the first place.

2. First-hand Information on Thai Research

Thai Prices

According to data from Thai statistical agencies, as the largest city in Thailand, the average monthly salary in Bangkok in 2022 was 22,274 baht (approximately 4,219 RMB). The cost of living in Bangkok is similar to that of second-tier cities in China. A meal can be solved at a street stall for 100 baht, and a meal in a food court in a large shopping mall can be settled for about 200 baht. In addition, the 7-Elevens that can be seen everywhere in Bangkok are also similar in price to domestic convenience stores.

Combined with the average monthly income of Bangkok, residents have a certain amount of entertainment consumption in their disposable income. Mobile games are a very popular form of entertainment for young people in Thailand, and making some recharges in mobile games is also very acceptable to many young people, which is one of the fundamental reasons why the Thai mobile game market is so hot.

 

Bottled water 10 baht (about 2 RMB)

–.

 

Tall can of Coca-Cola 16 baht (about 3.2 RMB)

Thai People’s Travel

Thailand is located in the south-central part of Asia, and it is hot most of the year. It happened to be midsummer when we went, so in many cases, there were fewer people walking on the street, and everyone chose to travel by motorcycle, car, etc. Thai universities generally have a large area, and many students also choose to use motorcycles to travel in school. Based on the characteristics of this national condition, in order to reach more young people and conduct street interviews in Thai universities, we chose more indoor places with a lot of traffic. When there are not many pedestrians on the road, it is difficult to invite students to do user testing and random interviews.

Entertainment Methods of Young People in Thailand

Different from China, there are few Internet cafes in Thailand and their business hours are short. An Internet cafe we found after walking for more than 20 minutes in Bangkok was only open from 2 pm to 10 pm. Through research, we found that many young people in Thailand said that they basically don’t go to Internet cafes. One of the reasons is that during the epidemic, Internet cafes were strictly controlled. Some people had their own PC devices or started playing mobile games. Combined with the factors such as the high cost performance and rapid technological upgrading of mobile devices, the share of mobile games in Thailand will be much higher than that of PC games.

 

Here, in addition to games, the most popular form of entertainment for young people is to gather with friends in board game cafes to play board games, or chat and play games in cafes. Most of these places also provide WIFI. Playing against/with friends has also become an important form of entertainment for them. No matter what they do, for many Thai players, having friends together is their most important entertainment condition. This is also one of the reasons why Thai players value social interaction so much in games.

 

Sports that Thai People Like

Thailand can be said to be a country of football. Football-related advertisements can be seen everywhere, and public football fields here are almost all open for free. Because there are many people playing, it is also common to see queues. At present, almost every province, county, and village in Thailand has its own non-professional team, and many schools also have their own school teams. Thai people like to play football and integrate football into their lives, which can also be seen in their TV dramas, movies, and public service advertisements.

The situation we observed in the sports field of the university was that there were only a few people playing basketball at about 4 pm, while there were already more than 10 people playing football. The love of Thai people for football is also reflected in the game market. The reason why the aforementioned eFootball2023 can occupy the top three of the mobile game best-selling list for a long time, and even occasionally compete for the first place, is inseparable from the fact that everyone loves this sport and the player base is large.

 

Thai People Like Personalized Content

From the perspective of game character selection, some players are not very impressed with some stars and big IPs in the game. On the contrary, they want to get a personalized experience in the game, such as playing a role like themselves in a game. When choosing a map they don’t like, they will also judge it based on reasons such as it being too popular, too common, and wanting a unique scene. On the streets of Bangkok, large-scale graffiti that can be seen everywhere is also a manifestation of personalization.

 

Mobile Device Selection

Among the research group, we found that most users mainly use Android phones, and the price is generally between 1,000 and 3,000 RMB. The price also limits the performance parameters of users’ mobile phones, and the limitation of mobile phone performance will lead to some rigid requirements for players’ choice of games. In addition, similar to other Southeast Asian countries, there are many Android mobile phone manufacturers in the Thai market, with a wide variety of models, and there are also a large number of old machines from many years ago, which also puts certain adaptation and optimization pressure on games that want to expand overseas to Thailand.

 

3. Reasons Why Thai Players Choose Games

In this research, based on the purpose of the research and previous assumptions, we mainly conducted street interviews on pedestrians on the streets of three cities in Thailand to understand their age, occupation, personal hobbies, game experience, etc. Based on some research results, here is a summary of the factors that Thai players value when choosing games:

Short Duration

Similar to white-collar workers in many countries, the working hours of white-collar workers in Bangkok, Thailand are generally 8-9 am to 5-6 pm, with an hour for lunch, including meals. White-collar workers do not have much time to spend on games during the day on weekdays, and many players tend to choose games with short single play times.

 

Some CBDs have a street of small stalls, and many white-collar workers choose to have lunch here

Preference for Japanese and Korean Art Styles

The art style is what many Thai players pay attention to first when they see advertisements. Whether they like the art style is an important factor in whether they will download the game. Thai players are more influenced by Japanese and Korean comics in terms of art, and they will prefer games with Japanese and Korean comic art style themes.

 

Bookstores in Thailand display many Japanese comics

Social Interaction

Social interaction is one of the reasons why Thai players pay great attention to when choosing games. Whether they can play with friends, and whether there is enough interaction when playing with friends, are important indicators that affect their choice of a game. Some players believe that even if a game is fun, they will not be able to continue to experience it in depth without friends; and even if a game is not very fond of the subject matter, playing with friends and being able to get a good enough interactive experience can also drive players to follow in the footsteps of their friends and play together. Not only games, but many activities in users’ lives are also for social purposes, such as playing basketball or other sports, which is just a form of gathering with friends.

4. Overseas Research Methods and Precautions

If you also want to do research in Thailand, how should you choose the research method, player recruitment, and research location?

First of all, it is recommended to find places in the target city where the target population may be more concentrated, and conduct preliminary site visits. Take Bangkok as an example, BTS stations, shopping malls, and university campuses are all places with a lot of traffic. However, not all locations are suitable for research. For example, people at BTS stations are in a hurry, and basically no one has time to accept interviews or research, let alone stop to test your game, even for a few minutes. Cafes and board game cafes near shopping malls or universities usually have a lot of free young people, and these places can be considered as priority locations for interviews. However, it should be noted that Thailand has begun to use PDPA laws. If you want to conduct interviews in places with a lot of traffic, you need to submit a written application to the local agency. At the same time, we recommend avoiding conducting research in some popular tourist attractions or airports, where most of the people encountered will be tourists, and it is conceivable that some errors may occur in the research results.

In terms of research methods, if there are no professional language personnel, you can choose a local supplier to provide freelancers for Thai language research; if the target group to be researched is relatively fixed, you can also recruit some players who are interested in participating in the research in advance before traveling. For example, if the target group is relatively young, you can contact some suppliers in advance to find players in the university who are interested in games or have similar game experience, and make appointments for all the time before departure, which can greatly improve the efficiency of interviews and research. Pay attention to arranging time for the executing freelancers to train in the interview outline and process to avoid problems such as inadequate implementation and insufficient results in the later stage; if it involves the execution of multiple player studies, after each test, you can promptly review the research situation of the day with the executing personnel, so as to make adjustments to the research plan in time, improve the execution details, and at the same time produce an agile summary, which will be able to complete the research of the day relatively comprehensively.

The important thing about overseas field research is to understand the local situation in advance; before traveling, determine the target population and master the living habits related to the target population and research purpose, such as entertainment methods, travel and consumption preferences, etc. This can improve efficiency in research, save execution time, and ensure the final research results.

5. Conclusion

Overall, Thailand’s Internet penetration rate is steadily increasing, the population structure is young, and the mobile game market still has great potential for development. It is a must-see place for games to expand overseas in Southeast Asia. This field research on Thai users can help us better understand the different regional markets in Thailand and all aspects of Thai game players, so that our games expanding overseas can better adapt to the local environment, reduce distribution risks, and provide a better game experience for a wider range of overseas players.

entry.title: The Third Aspect of Game Localization - How Important is Compliance Localization
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

 

In recent years, going global has become an unavoidable battle of strength and resources for Chinese game manufacturers.

The core of a game going global is “localization.” In addition to product, language, style, and cultural localization, understanding and adapting to the laws, regulations, and policies of the local overseas market is also a crucial part of localization.

Currently, there are four main legal compliance issues that deserve attention. First, the market access issue of “games going global”; second, overseas game rating systems; third, the cross-border data flow issue of “games going global”; and fourth, the consumer protection of “games going global.” We will elaborate on these with cases from different countries or regions.

1. Market Access Issues of “Games Going Global”

Taiwan, China

Currently, the game market in Taiwan, China is not directly open to mainland companies. The reason is that Taiwan’s “Cross-Strait People’s Relations Regulations” has the following local regulations: “Profit-making enterprises in the mainland area shall not engage in business activities in Taiwan unless they have been approved by the competent authority and have established a branch or office in Taiwan.”

If mainland game manufacturers publish games in Taiwan, they generally choose one of the following two methods:

  1. Cooperate with a local agent in Taiwan. For example, a mainland company acts as the game developer, and a Taiwan company acts as the game publisher and operator. According to Taiwan regulations, if the developer, producer, and publisher of the game are mainland-funded, the Taiwan agent should enter the game information and submit proof of agency before the game goes live.

  2. Establish an overseas company and launch the game in Taiwan through the Apple App Store and Google Play. However, in terms of specific game product promotion and marketing, mainland companies still need to cooperate with Taiwan companies.

Vietnam

Games are subject to government approval and licensing. Two licenses are required during the game’s operation: the first is the company’s operating qualification, and the second is the product’s launch license. Vietnam’s game publishing license regulations are relatively strict, and it takes about 6-9 months to apply for this license. However, given the qualifications and government review, not every publisher has sufficient conditions and capabilities to apply for a game license. At the same time, the Vietnamese government’s supervision of mobile games is also stricter than that of China. Therefore, Chinese developers who want to enter Vietnam must thoroughly study the relevant laws of Vietnam to avoid being unable to meet players in the region after making many preparations.

2. Overseas Game Rating Systems

South Korea

South Korea strictly implements a game rating system. The GRB rating standards have five levels: All Ages, 18+, 15+, 12+, and Test Level.

 

Among them, what needs special explanation and description is the “Test Level,” which means that game manufacturers can conduct preliminary public tests on the product’s stability and other aspects within 30 days before the official launch of the game product, and the exclusive “Test Level” logo should be placed at this time.

In addition, all games must not only place rating logos, but also display content logos (such as violence logos, tobacco, alcohol, and drug logos, sex logos, etc.) for content in the game that may have negative effects.

Japan

A game rating system already exists in the Japanese market. According to relevant Japanese regulations, game software is divided into five levels according to content, and provided to consumers of different ages according to specific ratings. The Computer Entertainment Rating Organization (CERO) classifies the levels based on whether the game content involves sexual performance, violent performance, anti-social behavior, language or thought, and the specific degree.

 

With the rise of mobile games, more games are provided to players through app stores. The Apple App Store and Google Play have their own rating standards for the games provided on their platforms. For example, the Apple App Store divides the games that can be listed into four main categories, and requires developers to fill in their own declarations according to the Apple rating standards when reviewing games.

United States

The United States is a pioneer in game rating systems. As early as the early 1990s, the undisguised violence in Mortal Kombat 2 caused a great backlash from public opinion, prompting the American game industry to unite and try to formulate a game rating system.

Currently, the United States generally implements the ESRB rating system, which is divided into six levels: E (Everyone), E10+ (Everyone 10+), T (Teen), M (Mature 17+), AO (Adults Only 18+), and RP (Rating Pending).

 

The above ratings apply not only to the game content itself, but also to game promotional advertisements. Although the ESRB rating system follows the principle of voluntariness, almost all games in Canada and the United States are rated, otherwise they may not be distributed to the public.

Many players also use the information of the ESRB rating to secretly infer whether a certain game is about to be launched, or the general content direction of the game.

3. Cross-border Data Flow Issues of “Games Going Global”

United States

CCPA is the abbreviation of The California Consumer Privacy Act of 2018. It is another information data protection bill introduced by California, USA on June 28, 2018, and officially implemented on January 1, 2020. It is known as the “strictest and most comprehensive personal privacy protection bill” in the United States.

 

The jurisdiction principle of CCPA is the principle of personality, that is, it only protects California residents. If every aspect of the game manufacturer’s information collection of players (including the player’s affiliation) is not in California, it is not subject to CCPA. However, since California has a population of more than 40 million, game manufacturers theoretically cannot distinguish whether players are California residents through IP addresses, and California is the most economically developed state in the United States, with the most prosperous Internet and technological innovation. Game manufacturers going global in the United States will inevitably be regulated by CCPA.

The main content of CCPA is actually to give players more control over the collection and management of their personal information by game manufacturers, including but not limited to: the right to know, the right to delete, the right to refuse, the right to opt-in, and the right to opt-out.

If the game manufacturer fails to follow the rules of CCPA, violates its obligations and fails to implement and maintain security procedures and take measures consistent with the nature of the information to protect the player’s personal information, thus suffering unauthorized access and leakage, theft or disclosure, the player can file a civil lawsuit. Game manufacturers may be required to pay each player $100-750 in damages or actual damages (whichever is greater), or face injunctions, etc.

EU

On May 25, 2018, the EU’s General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), known as the strictest data protection regulation in history, was officially implemented. It puts forward high requirements for enterprises to collect, store, protect, transfer, and use users’ personal information data within the EU. With its wide scope of application and severe penalties, it has aroused widespread concern among Chinese game companies going global.

 

According to Article 3 of the GDPR, game companies will be subject to the GDPR in the following situations: First, the game company has an establishment in the EU, regardless of whether its data processing behavior occurs in the EU; second, even if the game company’s place of business is not located in the EU, as long as it provides services to players in the EU (whether or not it charges players), or monitors the behavior of players in the EU.

For game companies going global that are subject to the GDPR, the consequences of violating the bill are very serious. According to Article 83 of the GDPR, the regulatory authority has the right to impose two levels of administrative penalties on enterprises for different illegal acts. The first level can be up to an administrative fine of 10 million euros, or an administrative fine of 2% of the enterprise’s total global turnover in the previous fiscal year (whichever is higher); the second level can be up to an administrative fine of 20 million euros, or an administrative fine of 4% of the enterprise’s total global turnover in the previous fiscal year (whichever is higher). When game companies go global in the EU, they should treat the GDPR bill with caution, and explain the scope of information collection, how it is stored, and how the information will be used in a simple and easy-to-understand form and language before collecting player personal information.

In May 2023, Meta was fined $1.2 billion for violating relevant provisions of the GDPR by transferring user data across borders to the United States, which is also the heaviest fine issued by EU regulators since the bill came into effect.

4. Consumer Protection Issues of “Games Going Global”

Japan

According to the “Online Game Operation Specifications” formulated by the Japan Computer Entertainment Supplier’s Association (CESA), games are required to clearly indicate the estimated amount of rare items obtained in the Gacha gameplay (similar to loot boxes) in the Gacha mechanism. The upper and lower limits of the Gacha drop rate must be provided in the Gacha machine; the respective drop rates are provided according to the types of Gacha items, etc.

Such regulations are similar to our domestic regulations on the publicity of draw probabilities - the main purpose is to prevent games from prompting users to overpay with unclear drop probabilities. The difference between the two is that the regulations on probability publicity in China are government regulations, while Japan is a self-regulatory norm of the association.

 

At the same time, in Article 3.1 of Apple’s “App Store Review Guidelines”, it has been clearly stated that apps that provide “loot boxes” or other mechanisms to purchase random virtual items must disclose the odds of obtaining each type of item to customers before they purchase. Therefore, manufacturers that provide games through the Apple App Store also need to comply with the regulation of random draw probability publicity.

United States

Loot boxes are an effective profit model explored by game manufacturers. Previously, the United States had not passed clear laws and regulations on loot box gameplay to ensure that the rights and interests of players were protected. Even if Hawaii had tried to make efforts, it had not passed any effective bills. Therefore, loot box gameplay is prevalent in the American game market.

But now this one of the world’s largest game markets has begun to legislate. In 2019, Republican lawmakers in the United States formally submitted a bill to Congress to prohibit game manufacturers from opening loot box gameplay to minors. This bill means that in all states of the United States, game companies will no longer be allowed to open loot box gameplay to minors under the age of 18, otherwise they may face corresponding fines.

 

Under the influence of this bill, Google added a new policy to Google Play, requiring games to clearly inform players of the drop rate of these items before they pay. At the same time, Google has added more restrictions to gambling games. “Cash and other items of value” that could originally be used as rewards are now strictly limited to “cash and other items of real value.”

Europe

European countries have also taken measures against the game loot box mechanism.

The Belgian Gaming Commission (BGC) issued a report on game loot boxes, defining this payment system as gambling, and stating that game companies that violate local laws will face fines to imprisonment. This directly led to the region lock of FIFA and Overwatch loot boxes, and Nintendo removed Fire Emblem Heroes and Animal Crossing: Pocket Camp from the Belgian region.

 

In the Netherlands, six members of parliament jointly submitted a bill to the House of Representatives to restrict game loot boxes, aiming to prohibit elements such as “loot boxes” and “gacha” from appearing in Dutch games. Members of parliament believe that this gameplay is essentially a kind of gambling, but it is covered with a layer of “micro-transactions” by manufacturers, and there is a possibility of attracting immature children to recharge to obtain benefits.

In addition, Spain has also submitted a new bill to restrict game loot boxes, which also strictly controls “loot boxes” and “gacha” elements, and is even more detailed than the Netherlands. It is reported that Spain’s new bill requires players to provide official age certificates, implement mandatory recharge limits, and require developers to disclose detailed odds of loot drops/draws, and impose stricter restrictions on “loot boxes” and “gacha”. Those who do not comply with the new regulations will be fined between 25 and 100 euros.

5. Conclusion

All in all, game companies going global is both an opportunity and a challenge. If you want to be invincible and forge ahead in the journey of going global, while building your own excellent game product strength, you need to pay attention to the various laws and regulations of the target market, as well as religious, cultural, customs and habits. In addition to completing text and cultural localization, it is necessary to do a good job of product compliance localization, pay attention to market access thresholds, game rating systems, cross-border data flow, and consumer protection issues.

entry.title: How Should Game Localization Deal with Slang
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

 

1. The Origin of “Slang” in Games

“Are you a GG or an MM?” “YYDS” “666” “GG”.

Even if you don’t play games, you can more or less hear these words or phrases in many situations in life. This kind of expression is the so-called “game slang”, most of which originated from the mouths of game players, and basically has some humorous color.

 

The so-called “slang” originally referred to some cryptic words created by various groups or communities in the civil society during the feudal society due to their cultural customs and communication needs. It was mainly used by people in the underworld to communicate privately and hide secrets. In modern times, after the development of the Internet, some special terms used on the Internet or in games are also called “Internet slang” or “game slang”.

The Internet and the game world are full of all kinds of players. As the saying goes, “Where there are people, there is a jianghu (江湖 - jiāng hú, literally “rivers and lakes”, referring to the martial arts world or the underworld)”. Therefore, players who walk in the game jianghu have gradually created sets of unique “game slang” that only people in their own circle can understand.

Not only in China, but many overseas games also have exclusive “slang” and are widely known. For example, “氪金 (kè jīn)” refers to the act of recharging in the game. This word is considered to be a transliteration and misreading of the Japanese word 課金 (かきん - kakīn). In Japanese, 課金 (kakīn) refers to the profit model of using cash to purchase game resources in the game. The transformation from “課金” to “氪金” is not simply because the two are pronounced similarly, but because in the “Burning Crusade” expansion of the game World of Warcraft, a rare ore translated as “Khorium” in the Chinese server was added. Due to its extremely valuable nature, this ore has always had a very high price. Therefore, after the rise of mobile games, some players linked “氪金” and “課金” together, not only because of the pronunciation, but also because of the value of the two.

 

Khorium ore in World of Warcraft

Why Does “Slang” Appear?

The reasons for the emergence of slang are diverse. One reason can be attributed to the fact that the names of equipment and skills in the game are too long, and they are not smooth to say in actual combat. For example, in the game EVE Online, game terms such as Warp Scrambler and Stasis Webifier are too tongue-twisting. When playing the game, saying the full name will affect the command, etc. Therefore, for convenience, these equipment will be referred to according to the equipment effect or the abbreviation of the equipment name. For example, the slang of the Warp Scrambler mentioned above is “long point” (长反 - cháng fǎn) because it has a longer range, but the warp disruption strength caused is lower, and it cannot close the microwarpdrive. In addition to weapons, equipment, and skills, players will also “attack” the names of heroes. Many games have also given many “slang names” to some heroes due to players’ consensus on the appearance, skills, and background of these heroes.

It is not difficult to see from the above that the “slang” that appears in the game is generally for the convenience of players to communicate when playing. In a fast-paced online game, players generally do not have much time to type, and the game itself only provides some very simple signals to help players communicate quickly. Therefore, players will invent “slang”, which is generally short and vivid.

Of course, the emergence and spread of game slang cannot be separated from the “humorous and comedic” effect. When a particular expression can achieve a strong comedic effect in a certain situation, players will start to use it frequently in other similar scenes. Coupled with the entertainment attributes of the game itself, this slang will naturally begin to spread widely.

2. “Slang” Appearing in Overseas and Domestic Multiplayer Online Games

Most overseas and domestic games have unique “slang” tables, including everything from in-game character names to game items, to various sentences and words used by players when communicating in the game community, as well as their abbreviations and nicknames. We will take the Chinese, Japanese, and English versions of Naraka: Bladepoint as the main examples to summarize the frequently appearing game “slang” and their meanings.

As a multiplayer online game with a multiplayer team mode, Naraka: Bladepoint has also spawned a lot of “slang” in social aspects. In addition to text, this “slang” also exists in the form of emoji and kaomoji, which plays a great role in player communication in the game community.

In Naraka: Bladepoint’s Chinese server duos or trios teams, you often hear words like “帮我拆火 (bāng wǒ chāi huǒ - help me break the fire)”, “咱们去空投 (zán men qù kōng tóu - let’s go to the airdrop)”, “猛蓄猛出 (měng xù měng chū - fierce charge and release)”, “压力怪 (yā lì guài - pressure monster)”, “拉我 (lā wǒ - pull me)” and so on. These slang words may sound confusing to players who don’t play this game, but they are familiar to veteran players. The word “拆火” means to help teammates fight against the enemy and interfere when teammates are attacked by the enemy, so as to achieve the purpose of dispersing firepower. “空投” in Naraka: Bladepoint refers to the supplies dropped in the safe zone, “Airdrop”. The meaning of “猛蓄猛出” is easy to understand, referring to players who only charge and release directly. “压力怪” does not mean that they feel a lot of pressure, but usually refers to people who “put pressure” on their teammates in the game to achieve their own emotional venting. There are many ways to exert pressure, such as verbal pressure (ridicule, abuse) and behavioral pressure (malicious interference), etc. Chinese server players even change the part of speech of the name “压力” into a verb, creating new “slang” in the form of “pressure teammates”.

 

Some of the Slang in Naraka: Bladepoint

When studying the “slang” of Naraka: Bladepoint‘s English and Japanese regions, we found that the “slang” used by overseas players when chatting in the game community is mostly abbreviations of daily expressions and game terms, followed by emoji. We have summarized some of them in the table below.

 

Table 1: A List of “Slang” in the English and Japanese Communities of Naraka: Bladepoint

3. Challenges of “Slang” Translation in the Localization Process

It can be seen from the table above that the “slang” in English and Japanese includes abbreviations, generalizations and codes of game terms and daily expressions. There are also direct use of pictures, such as emoji, or kaomoji to express one’s feelings more vividly.

Some of these “slang” are even very similar to those we use in China. For example, English players will use “rmb” to refer to the “right mouse button” in the game, and Japanese players will use “草 (kusa - grass)” to express “laugh” or “www” (the Japanese onomatopoeia for laughter sounds). However, it should be noted that although the two are very similar and even written the same way, their meanings are completely different in different language environments. In addition, “slang” is often concise, obscure, and targeted. Not to mention foreign players, some new players in the server do not understand it at all. Therefore, in the process of game localization translation, how to translate these “slang” so that players of the corresponding language can also quickly understand the meaning it conveys and facilitate smoother communication between players has become a major challenge in the localization process.

Breaking Through the Cultural Barriers of Corresponding Language Countries

Different regions have different cultures. The differences between one culture and other cultures constitute cultural barriers, which are mainly reflected in the differences in language, way of thinking, customs, religious beliefs, moral standards, political and legal systems, and outlook on life, world outlook, and values. In the localization process of a game dominated by multiplayer gameplay, the localization team needs to consider the convenience of communication between players, and focus on translating by studying the cultural characteristics of the target area and the style of “slang” in other games in the area.

 

Unlike in other countries, GG in China has a negative connotation.

In English-speaking regions, players are more inclined to abbreviate in-game props and terms, or abbreviate two words after splicing them together to achieve the purpose of fast typing and communication; Japanese players tend to create “slang” based on the characteristics of game terms (appearance, etc.) combined with local culture. As mentioned above, “Fiddlesticks” is called “かかし (kakashi)” because “かかし (kakashi)” originally means scarecrow in Japanese, and the surname of “Kakashi Hatake” in Naruto is “Hatake”, which can be translated as “rice field”. Therefore, Japanese players will associate the two. In addition, many “草 (kusa)” Internet buzzwords suddenly appeared in Japan in 2022 because the Romaji of “笑 (warai - laugh)” in Japanese is “warau”, so “www” is used to express laughter, and “w” looks like a bunch of grass, so “笑 (warai)” is replaced by “草 (kusa)” in Japanese Internet buzzwords.

Therefore, if you want to translate the “slang” in the game well, you must first be among the player groups, understand the local culture, and understand what kind of terms players in the target market will use in their daily lives, and what the structure of these terms is. When literal translation is not possible, by tracing the composition of the term and translating its origin, the word can be translated more accurately. This requires actively participating in the community of the target language during localization, mastering the rules of “slang” in a large number of daily communication with players, becoming familiar with the local culture, understanding the cultural differences between the two countries, and striving to break through cultural barriers.

4. Conclusion

At present, domestic games are booming in overseas markets, but for mature markets such as Japan, South Korea, Europe and the United States, local game manufacturers or global top manufacturers have generally been deeply involved for many years and have strong competitive barriers. Coupled with the cultural differences between the two places, the competitiveness of the overseas expansion of domestic games has gradually increased. Domestic games can build a bridge of communication between players of the two languages through localization, reduce cultural barriers through localization, spread excellent culture, so that games not only “go out” overseas, but also “stand firm”. Through localization, games can be culturally empowered, and appropriate “slang” can form another link between games and players, and players and players.

entry.title: How Localization Shapes Character Image - Taking Japanese Localization as an Example
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

 

1. Localization and Character Image

Localization is the process of adapting a product or service to the differences of different markets. It is often confused with translation, but it actually goes far beyond the scope of translation. Translation is only one of several services that make up the localization process.

In addition to translation, the localization process may also include adjusting graphics according to the target market, modifying the content layout to adapt to the translated text, converting to local currency, using the correct date, address, and data formats, adapting to local regulations, interface and skin adjustments, etc. The object of localization is the “product”, not just the “text”; this process also includes two aspects: language and culture (including social background).

In the localization of game products, the process is, in a sense, a re-creation of the game content (such as character image). There are a thousand Hamlets in a thousand people’s eyes. Even people in the same language environment cannot reach a consensus on the same thing, and it is even more difficult for people in different languages and regions to have the same understanding of the same thing. Therefore, in addition to the character image created by the original language, the shaping of the character image by the target language is particularly important.

A successful re-creation of the character image must be an indispensable part of successful localization. However, while re-creating the character image, the localization process must not deviate from the original image of the character (that is, the character image in the original language). This is because localization not only needs to meet the requirements of the target market, but also needs to carry the information of the original language and the original game itself. In this way, how to shape a “new image” that is close to the character’s original image becomes a problem. This is a challenge of “dancing in shackles”, and it is also an opportunity to gain both overseas market revenue and the inheritance of national culture.

2. Localization Strategies for Language and Culture

Language Localization: Domestication of Language Usage Habits

The localization of the language itself is often understood as localization translation, which is only one aspect. When it comes to the standards of Chinese people for translation, it is impossible to avoid Yan Fu’s “faithfulness, expressiveness, and elegance” mentioned in “Evolution and Ethics”. In the process of localizing the background, plot, lines, etc. related to the character image, this standard will also be referred to. “Faithfulness means truth, and truth means non-falsehood; expressiveness means attainment, and attainment means neither excess nor deficiency; elegance means literariness, and literariness means being elegant when it should be elegant and being vulgar when it should be vulgar.”

Lawrence Venuti put forward the concepts of domestication and foreignization in his book The Translator’s Invisibility: A History of Translation. Domestication emphasizes reducing the sense of strangeness in the target language, while foreignization preserves the exotic elements in the original language.

In language localization, if you want to ensure that the character image is close to the prototype, you must first ensure the correctness of the language itself, including no grammatical errors, no deviations in word interpretation. This is the basis of all localization and translation. If the foundation is not strong, the character image on the upper level will also shake. After ensuring the correctness of the language itself, what needs to be done is “expressiveness”, neither excess nor deficiency.

In the current era of big data, with the help of AI translation and the excellent quality monitoring of the localization team, the correctness and quality of the language can be well guaranteed in most cases and scenarios, so “faithfulness” and “expressiveness” are no longer difficult.

The final “elegance” is the key factor that determines whether a localization result is of high quality in this era. How to analyze, discuss, and reshape the style, usage habits, and the character image behind the original language, and apply it to the target language, so that the target language population (that is, game players in countries and regions that use the target language) can feel that the translated language is not awkward, then it can be called a successful localization.

For example, in the Japanese original of Blue Archive, Iori calls Aiko “アコちゃん”, which is often translated as “A-ko chan” in anime scenarios, but the localization team of the simplified Chinese version translated it as “Aya”(亚亚). Obviously, the localization here removes the influence of Japanese usage habits without reducing Iori’s original intimacy with the members of the Gehenna Prefect Team. This localized translation even reminds people of the names of giant pandas, which has a strong Chinese flavor. In a sense, it can be called a successful localization attempt.

 

Cultural Localization: Foreignization of Historical and Cultural Factors

Cultural localization is different from language localization. If language localization requires the character image to be as close as possible to the target language user group, then cultural localization requires the character image to maintain a certain distance from the target group in some aspects. In our view, we must provide players with a reason to play our games.

Why would a player in a country choose not to play their own country’s games, but to choose a game from a foreign manufacturer? There can be many reasons for this, such as rich gameplay/playability, extremely high picture quality, vivid story background/character plot, comprehensive user service, etc. Of course, many players themselves are only loyal to the game category and overall quality, and do not care about the developer’s region. However, in the world of games, which highly emphasizes subjective user experience, how to enter the player’s mind is decisive. At this time, if a game can bring players a foreign cultural experience that starts with curiosity and ends with dissemination, it can clearly distinguish this game from other games; and it is this differentiation that can make a game from a foreign country for players stand out. At this time, the character image should be closer to the background story of the original language, rather than the environment of the target language.

 

For example, in the preheating story of Naraka: Bladepoint‘s Yoto Hime, there is such a passage: “Beast?” The girl seemed to have heard something very interesting, and couldn’t help laughing softly.

The first version of the Japanese translation was: 「ペット？」少女はなにか面白いことを聞いたかのように、思わず笑った。

However, considering that Naraka: Bladepoint is based on a fictional ancient Chinese fantasy and martial arts world, the word ペット in Japanese is derived from the English word pet, which reflects the epitome of English’s influence in the world. Therefore, after consideration, we changed this passage to:

「飼い犬？」少女はなにか面白いことを聞いたかのように、思わず笑った。

Here, 飼い犬 is often translated as a domestic dog, which is closer to the Eastern worldview of Naraka: Bladepoint than pet, and the character image of Yoto Hime in this worldview can be better shaped. Indeed, in terms of language usage habits, for Japanese people, the word pet is more commonly used and more everyday than domestic dog. But as mentioned above, how can a game localization that cannot be distinguished from other games and cannot bring players a sense of foreign culture break through the vast game market today? Therefore, the localization process here must follow the principle of foreignization of historical and cultural factors to a certain extent.

Looking back, the translation of “Aya” in Blue Archive mentioned above does achieve language localization, but it seems to have eliminated most of the cultural perception of anime, which may bring some players a sense of separation between the picture and the characters.

3. Successful Localization Cases

How do successful cases make the character image more popular with the local audience through localization? Here are some examples of Japanese localization and translation to better understand the two key points of shaping the character image: domestication of language usage habits and foreignization of historical and cultural factors.

Yoto Hime of Naraka: Bladepoint is portrayed in the game as a princess/lady whose underlying logic is to find “fun”. Therefore, there are a lot of Japanese final particles (language usage habits) such as わ, よ, かしら, じゃない in the script to reflect this princess persona. The following is also a passage from Yoto Hime’s preheating story:

“He said yesterday that he never believed in ghosts and gods. I wanted to see if it was true~ Who knew that it would be amazing once I tried. I can’t really accept him as a disciple, so I had to let this beggar receive his bows for me.”

「あの奴、昨日自分で言ったでしょ、鬼神の説を信じていないって。だから本当かどうかを見てみたいわ。試した結果、大変なことになっちゃったわよ。ほら、私は彼を本当に弟子にするのもいかないし、物乞いくんに拝礼を受けてもらうしかないわ。」

However, in the first version of the preheating story, this persona was only reflected in Yoto Hime’s actions in the plot, and her unique style was not shown in her lines. After discussion by the localization team, these simple modal final particles were finally added according to Yoto Hime’s persona in the script, shaping Yoto Hime who is close to the original persona at the language level.

 

4. Conclusion

In all the above examples, it seems that the localization discusses and纠结s over only one or two words or pronunciations. In fact, whether it is the image of a character, or the game background and world created by various characters, and even the entire game, will be affected by these seemingly insignificant, accumulated details. The character image reshaped by localization must show the characteristics of being close to the original language but not rigid, and being compatible with the target language but vivid in insignificant places.

Therefore, in localization work, the more insignificant the place, the more effort should be made to ensure the rigor of the localization work. Although the behavior of the character itself is ever-changing, the behavioral logic behind the character should be consistent, and the identity of the character we create should also be the same and continuous. The consistency of the appropriate expression of the same thing between different languages is also something we should firmly grasp.

entry.title: How to Choose the Right Font for Your Game
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

 

Text in games runs through the core gameplay and functional interfaces at all levels. The information transmission and emotional expression it achieves are key elements in game interaction. This article analyzes the characteristics of font design in excellent game works at home and abroad under different themes, and discusses how to choose the basic tone of fonts and the integration of font design and game worldview according to the style of different games. In addition, we will also explain the relevant information about game font localization and commercial costs. These contents are intended to provide game developers with ideas and references for font selection and design.

1. Font Classification

There are many ways to classify fonts, such as handwriting, printing, and artistic fonts… etc. The most discussed classification method is “serif and sans-serif”. In layman’s terms, serifs are also known as “feet”. Serif fonts are fonts with corner decorations. As can be clearly seen from the figure below, at the same font size, the angular sans-serif font looks larger and clearer than the serif font.

 

Figure 1. Comparison of Serif and Sans-serif Fonts

Serif

It is generally believed that serif fonts originated from Roman stone inscriptions. The modern explanation for these decorative strokes, which is accepted by most people, comes from Father Edward Catich’s book “The Origin of the Serif”. The book believes that Roman letters were first written with a square-tipped brush before being carved into stone tablets. Due to the use of a square-tipped brush, the strokes would have uneven strokes at the beginning and end, so finishing actions were added at the beginning, end, and corners of the strokes. The engravers carved according to the written samples, which naturally formed the “serif” serif font.

In ancient Chinese characters, such as Song typeface, at the junction of strokes, the beginning of vertical strokes and the end of horizontal strokes, due to the return and pause of the brush when writing calligraphy, a unique triangular structure is formed, which can also be called “serif”.

Sans-serif

In the era of electronic screens, the display of Chinese characters does not need the original function of “serif” but only retains its decorative nature. However, in the case of a large amount of text information input/output on the Internet, too many embellishments on the strokes of serif fonts can easily cause visual fatigue. Sans-serif fonts, contrary to serif fonts, have no decorative lines or small horizontal lines similar to “small feet” in their glyphs, and the text is usually composed of mechanical and uniform lines.

There is no unified rule when choosing fonts, but there are some default norms. For example, long-form reading or small-screen information displays prefer to use sans-serif fonts; while titles or small-scale texts prefer serif fonts to enhance the beauty of short sentences. Moreover, in many scenarios, more irregular artistic fonts are needed to render the atmosphere of the game or achieve specific effects.

2. Selection of Game Fonts

Game Style Determines the Basic Tone

In the selection and design of game fonts, it is necessary to consider the game style, type, main audience, and the good integration within the different systems in the game and the game worldview. However, there are many ways to classify game styles, and it is difficult to find a specific classification method to cover all game types and styles. Here, some examples with obvious contrasts are used to illustrate the differences in the form of different fonts and the selection principles.

In terms of gameplay type, games that are more mysterious and magical usually prefer serif fonts, while action games that emphasize fast pace and dynamism will prefer sans-serif fonts to reflect a crisp power; Chinese style games and styles that are more realistic and nostalgic always prefer serif fonts to create a real, profound and immersive atmosphere; while sci-fi and anime games emphasize exploration and technology, and choosing sans-serif fonts will be more compatible with them; for children’s games, cartoon and simple sans-serif fonts are usually the first choice.

 

Figure 2. Different style classifications of games and the types of fonts that can be selected

If the worldview of the game has not been determined during the design process, you can initially choose a suitable basic font tone by combining the keyword list provided in the figure below. Generally speaking, sans-serif fonts are suitable for modern, concise, technological and other game styles; while serif fonts are more suitable for traditional, ancient, Gothic fantasy and other game styles. There is no clear boundary for the selection of fonts. On the basis of ensuring information transmission, it is often pursued to create a visual performance effect that is more in line with the game worldview.

 

Figure 3. Correspondence between game style keywords and font selection recommendations

Of course, choosing sans-serif or serif as the main font of the game does not mean that all text content in the game is immutable. There are also various font classifications in the game, and it is often necessary to mix and use multiple fonts.

System Fonts and Artistic Fonts

Whether it is a serif font or a sans-serif font, it needs to be authorized before it can be legally used as the system font of the game. Due to the size and compression restrictions of the game package, too many fonts cannot be placed in the game, and usually one font is selected for each of the title font and the system font. However, it would be a bit monotonous if all the text in the game only uses the system font, so developers need to make a trade-off in the use of fonts.

In order to meet some special needs in the game, such as event titles, game names, etc., developers may need to use some artistic fonts or handwritten fonts.
