Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

 

1. Mainstream Game Payment Models

You’ve probably heard the saying, “Buy early, enjoy early; buy late, enjoy discounts; don’t buy, get it for free.” After a game’s initial priced release, there’s usually a relatively long period of price stability, which is the main source of revenue for new games in their early stages. After a period of stable operation, there might be limited-time discounts at certain points, such as during Steam sales, to attract hesitant players.

And for some games, the final stage is to completely remove the payment barrier after a long period of operation and switch to free-to-play. PUBG, released in 2017 with an initial price of $29.99 (98 yuan in China), became a free-to-play game in January 2022. Fall Guys, released in August 2020 with an initial price of $19.99 (58 yuan in China), became free-to-play in June 2022. Overwatch went free-to-play when its sequel, Overwatch 2, was released.

 

In summary, whether in China or abroad, there are mainly three payment models for online games: The first is buy-to-play, where you pay to purchase the experience qualification and obtain permanent access to the game after payment; examples include Rainbow Six Siege, New World, and Baldur’s Gate 3.

The second is free-to-play, where there is no barrier to entry, replaced mainly by in-game store purchases. Examples include DOTA 2 and Apex Legends.

The third is a time-based subscription model, where players purchase points to exchange for game time, paying for how much they play. Examples include World of Warcraft and Fantasy Westward Journey. This payment model will not be discussed in this article.

So, what are the advantages and disadvantages of these different payment models? Why do some developers choose to switch from paid to free, and what issues do game companies need to face when making this decision?

Buy-to-Play Games

For buy-to-play games, the main advantages are:

  • Game quality is usually relatively higher: Generally speaking, with similar investment budgets, the quality of buy-to-play games is relatively higher than that of free games. They need to attract players to overcome the payment barrier and try the game with quality. If the manufacturer does not have excellent graphics and core gameplay, it will be difficult to obtain sufficient revenue and reputation from selling the game. Compared with free games that profit from in-game stores, buy-to-play games save a lot of development and design resources on payment and long-term content. Therefore, they have enough manpower and resources to invest in game quality, concentrate on targeted design, and provide players with a better gaming experience.

  • Has a certain threshold, fewer cheaters: For players who use illegal software, they need to pay for the game again for each account they change. Increasing the cost of cheating for players by buying out also has a certain inhibitory effect on the proliferation of cheating to a certain extent.

Of course, sometimes the threshold limit is also one of its shortcomings. The mode of paying to purchase an admission ticket will also prevent some players from entering the game, especially since most AAA games are not cheap at the time of their initial release, which will become a factor hindering players from purchasing the game for players with different consumption levels.

Free Games

For free games, the biggest advantage is that there is no threshold. As long as the device can handle it, anyone can enter the game and experience it. Although everyone has different game preferences, and many players will find that they are not the target audience and lose interest in the game after trying it out, due to the large base of new players, the number of players who finally stay in the game may be more than that of some buy-to-play games.

Why do companies like Bluehole, Valve, and Activision Blizzard choose to make originally paid games free? From the data point of view, when making such a decision, the game is likely to have gone downhill for a while, and the number of retained players continues to decrease. Switching to free-to-play is also largely to attract more players who are kept out by the payment barrier. PUBG, a once-phenomenal game, has seen its DAU continue to decline since it reached its online peak in 2018 due to various reasons. By the end of 2021, the average number of online players in the game had fallen below 150,000, and the peak online was only about one-tenth of the peak. After announcing the switch to free-to-play, many free players poured in, the peak number of online players in the game almost doubled, and the average number of online players also increased significantly. Fall Guys, also a game that requires a high number of concurrent players, had very strong data in the early days of its launch, but as its popularity gradually declined, its developers were also considering how to extend the life of the game. After its decision to switch to free-to-play, the total number of players worldwide quickly exceeded 20 million, and exceeded 50 million within 2 weeks, further achieving a large-scale breakthrough in the user base.

 

PUBG experienced a peak online of more than 3.2 million in 2018, and the number of players continued to decline.

2. What Issues Should Be Paid Attention to When a Game Goes Free-to-Play?

Although the effect is good, going free-to-play is not a tool that a game can casually use to attract players. If the following problems are not properly handled, it may have the opposite effect.

Compensation for Veteran Players Needs to Be in Place

Players who purchased the game before it went free-to-play are people who spent real money to buy the game and experience it. For developers, this part of the players needs more attention and maintenance. Game manufacturers cannot only focus on attracting new players and not do their best to retain existing veteran players. If the compensation given by the manufacturer to veteran players is sincere and attractive enough, it will also attract a large number of veteran players to return; if the compensation is stingy, veteran players will not only not buy it, but may also give the game a bad review because they feel betrayed, ruining the reputation.

 

In this regard, Naraka: Bladepoint directly returned the money spent by veteran players to purchase the game in equal proportion as in-game currency when it went free-to-play, so that everyone said “misunderstanding resolved” after learning about the compensation benefits, and called it a great deal; there were even many new players who directly purchased the game at the original price after seeing the news, and then waited for the refund of gold ingots. On the day of the free-to-play launch, Naraka: Bladepoint sold another 1 million copies, once again climbing to the second place on the Steam sales list, and even the official website was overloaded by enthusiastic players.

 

Live broadcast of Naraka: Bladepoint announcing free-to-play (left) and announcing compensation rewards for veteran players (right)

Anti-Cheat Work

When a game becomes free, it means that there is no payment barrier for anyone to enter the game, and the soil of low account cost is particularly prone to breeding cheating and forming a proliferation. In a fair competitive environment, it is devastating to the game experience of normal players. When criminals can cheat at almost no cost, the gaming experience of normal players will be greatly affected. Especially for tactical competitive games, one cheating player will affect nearly 60 or even 100 normal players in the same game. One-shot headshots and ignoring control make the game experience very bad.

Before going free-to-play, PUBG has been criticized by players for cheating. After going free-to-play, it did not make effective restrictions on cheating. It only launched casual mode and competitive mode to separate paid players and free players when it switched to free. However, not all players are keen on competitive mode. In a mode where cheating is rampant and cannot be banned for a long time, any type of player will have a hard time having a good gaming experience.

Fall Guys, which also became a free-to-play game in 2022, has also been plagued by cheating, and is jokingly called “Fairy Bean Man” by players. The gameplay of Fall Guys is a casual level-breaking type, and the number of players in a single game is also large. One person cheating can make all players in this game restart directly.

 

Before going free-to-play, Naraka: Bladepoint also realized that once the game is open for free play, a large number of players will flood in, including criminals who intend to cheat. To this end, the development team made preparations in advance and banned 2,754 players who used cheats on the day of the free-to-play launch; at the same time, they also deducted the rank points of 163 players who “rode the cheat car” to warn all new and old players not to try to benefit from cheating, and to maintain a fair game environment in a timely manner.

New Player’s Novice Period Experience Issues

For new players, getting started with an old game that has been in operation for a period of time has a high cost. Veteran players have gone through a lot of training and have mastered many game skills, but new players don’t know anything when they enter the game, which can easily bring them some uncontrollable frustration. After the game goes free-to-play, on the one hand, the game needs to optimize the novice guide, teaching and other onboarding issues to lead new players to quickly master the game. Especially for some new players who have not necessarily been familiar with action games before, this group of non-core players and general players especially need strong novice guidance to teach and retain them. On the other hand, the game also needs to make more optimizations in the matching mechanism, reasonably allocate the rank difference of players in the game, and prevent the “smurfing” behavior of veteran players from leading to the direct churn of new players.

Novice guidance has always been a very important module of Naraka: Bladepoint. When it went free-to-play, the game deliberately added a lot of special training in the practice mode, including basic parry practice, charged attack followed by parry practice, jump parry practice, and higher-level operations such as dodge parry and grapple parry. Many of these operations require players to accumulate a certain amount of game time and number of games, and they can only be mastered skillfully after learning in actual combat. Putting them in the practice mode can facilitate players who are not familiar with action operations to carry out more practical exercises, accelerate the learning efficiency, and experience the joy of parrying faster.

 

Naraka: Bladepoint’s new novice special training module

3. Conclusion

Going free-to-play is not a panacea for a game to revive when its popularity declines. If the decision to go free-to-play and the compensation plan are not fully considered, it may backfire and accelerate the decline of the game. Going free-to-play needs to carefully consider the different needs of new and old players, and ensure the game experience of all types of players, so that the game can have more players to play when it goes free-to-play, and the environment in the game can develop in a more balanced and healthy direction.

entry.title: Why Are Players Obsessed with Virtual Avatars: From Custom Character Creation to Fashion Outfits
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

 

From the Barbie doll, popular in the toy market in 1959 for its interchangeable clothing, to the QQ Show, familiar to Generation Z, with its customizable outfits and interactive expressions, and from early single-player dress-up games with fixed character images and clothing to highly customizable online character creation systems with hundreds of body parameters. The game format of dressing up characters has been popular from the beginning, and after becoming a virtual avatar online, it has developed rapidly due to its freedom of appearance customization, and has gained a lot of attention and recognition from players.

Early Barbie dolls with various career images

In 2023, after the first cloud character creation experience of Justice Online mobile game was launched, it set a record for simultaneous online players within ten minutes. The topic of “part-time game character creators earning over 10,000 yuan per month” was once on the Weibo hot list, attracting widespread attention and discussion. The hottest character creation data in the official character creation station has more than 50,000 downloads, and the sharing and exchange of character creation data among active players in social media has become a daily routine, which shows that there is a huge demand for character creation among players in the game.

Why can character creation, as a form of shaping virtual images, trigger a player experience frenzy and demand far beyond everyone’s expectations? It is also worth thinking about why selling game fashion and appearances has become a business model accepted by players around the world. Why are players willing to pay for some high-quality and exquisite fashion that can only be worn in virtual images?

Next, this article will start from the psychological connection between the player and the game character, and analyze the reasons why players are so concerned about the fashion, character creation and other appearances of game characters.

I. Game Characters are Players’ Virtual Avatars

The avatar identification theory proposes that in the game environment, players project their self-identity onto the game character through interaction with the game character, forming a special psychological connection.

The Origin of the Term Avatar

The original Zelda game first allowed players to customize the protagonist’s name, and subsequent games gradually began to allow players to customize the protagonist’s clothing and appearance. Later, it was collectively referred to as: Avatar system. The word Avatar comes from Sanskrit. In Hinduism, Avatar is a special ability user who can change his image, and is generally regarded as the image of gods in the human world. That is to say, the game character, that is, the avatar, is the digital representation of the player, and the player imagines and experiences the emotions and viewpoints of the character from the game character.

Avatar and Projection

Freud’s theory of personality structure believes that a person is composed of three parts: id, ego, and superego. The “id” follows the pleasure principle and contains a group of chaotic, instinctive, and suppressed desires. The “ego” follows the reality principle and satisfies the needs of the id under the conditions of real environment and moral standards. The “superego” follows the moral principle and contains moral ideals and conscience.

However, in real life, many desires of the id are restricted and cannot be realized. For example, office workers cannot travel and enjoy the beautiful mountains and rivers as they wish, but they can log in to the Justice Online game in their spare time and explore mountains and rivers in the dreamy and beautiful environment, so that their leisure exploration desires can be satisfied in another way.

 

《Justice Online》 Mobile Game Scene

The same is true in terms of appearance. For example, the Justice Online mobile game fashion [Star Palace] Pegasus skirt’s elegant and gorgeous design and court style can enable players to realize the dream of becoming a gorgeous female star that is difficult to achieve in daily life. It is the existence of a virtual avatar. It allows the desires for unfulfilled behaviors and appearances to have an object of projection and another possibility of realization.

 

《Justice Online》 Mobile Game Theme Fashion [Star Palace]

II. Character Appearance Promotes Avatar Identification

Studies have shown that avatars are not only seen as characters temporarily manipulated by players, but players also regard avatars as part of their self-concept. So how does this psychological connection explain players’ obsession with appearance and character creation?

The similarity between the virtual avatar and the player in terms of physical appearance, personality characteristics, race, etc. can promote the realization of avatar identification. When players choose or customize virtual images in the game, they are often based on the psychological mechanism of self-identification and projection. They hope to show their personality, interests, or ideal self through the character image in the game. This is why most players’ game character creation results have characteristics that are in line with their own aesthetics and character style settings

The game has developed a function in the character creation module that allows intelligent character creation based on pictures uploaded by players, allowing players who are not good at character creation to restore their beauty in the game with the help of AI tools. In addition, many players upload not photos of celebrity beauties, but their own photos. In the game, players actually carry out a kind of emotional projection by choosing or customizing the appearance of the character. With the support of AI technology and the addition of exquisite costumes in game design, virtual characters can be infinitely close to a player’s ideal image of themselves. What players project is the beautiful image they want to become, as players say: “Pinch yourself into a beautification, and what you pinch out is what I hope to grow into..

 

《Justice Online》 Character Creation System

III. Specific Appearance is a Mask to Switch Identities

In the virtual world of online games, players project the desires they want to satisfy in the id, and the images they have not pursued in reality, onto the avatar.

The Proteus Effect

The Proteus effect shows that when individuals are given specific character traits, they tend to behave in a manner consistent with those traits. This phenomenon originally came from the sea god Proteus in ancient Greek mythology, who had the ability to change his appearance, so the word “Proteus” is also used to refer to “ready to change shape and personality at any time”. In the game, by choosing or customizing the appearance and dress of the character, the player is actually setting a specific character image for himself, and showing the corresponding behavior pattern under this image.

The Mask Function of Character Image

We can regard such a specific appearance image as a kind of “mask”, which is a symbol and sense of ritual to switch identities, and it is also a prop to increase the immersion of the new identity. In Naraka: Bladepoint, a national style martial arts game, in addition to the antique scenes, the ancient style appearance of the characters also allows players to quickly feel that they can travel to ancient times, and Ning Hongye’s blindfolded cloth strips and capable and neat fashion can also allow players to substitute into a brave and decisive swordsman identity.

 

《Naraka: Bladepoint》 Ning Hongye

And when this “mask” does not meet the player’s conditions for identity setting, there will be a sense of incongruity. Therefore, in the design of game fashion, not only should we start from the era background and identity of the game character itself, but also combine the player’s inherent cognition of the character or a certain type of image to think.

Conclusion

Game characters are players’ virtual avatars in another world. Appearance customization and other features can promote players’ identification with the avatar. Players will invest their imagination of their ideal self in the avatar. Different appearance images are like a mask, allowing players to be more deeply immersed in the role of the game.

Of course, such projection cannot explain all players’ appearance settings for game characters. Perhaps in the eyes of some players, game character creation and fashion matching are a way of personalized self-expression. By choosing different appearances and dresses, players can show their uniqueness and creativity.

entry.title: Unveiling the Design Behind Horror Game Jumpscares and Players' Cognitive Load
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

 

Horror works often use jumpscares as one of the basic building blocks of horror. This technique uses sudden scene changes and sound effects to make the player or audience “jump.”

Christopher Robert Cargill, screenwriter for the Sinister film series, explained the principle of jumpscares: “Jumpscares work because there’s misdirection. A successful jumpscare is like a magic trick. I’ll make you look over here, and I’ll do something over there, and then suddenly—bang!—something will scare you.”

As early as the 1976 film Carrie, the jumpscare at the end made the audience shudder: when the audience thought everything was over and saw Sue peacefully visiting Carrie’s grave with flowers, they would be scared by the hand that suddenly came out of the grave.

 

Jumpscare in 《Carrie》

Similar jumpscare designs are also common in game scenes. In horror games, players usually perform a distracting task, such as finding items or solving puzzles, and the jumpscare will come at this unsuspecting moment. In the game Resident Evil Village, released in 2021, you can see players being startled by zombies that suddenly appear with the music while exploring.

 

Jumpscare in 《Resident Evil: Village》

At the end of 2023, a horror game Lethal Company exploded among game streamers, winning the Steam “Better With Friends” award of the year, and the highest daily views on Twitch reached 190,000. Kelsey Raynor, an editor at VG247, pointed out, “…although the blocky graphics may make the game seem incomparable to other horror masterpieces, Lethal Company still fascinates a large number of fans, and its weird aesthetics is obviously part of the game’s charm.” Gabriel Moss, an editor at IGN, also mentioned, “ Lethal Company is already a sensory miracle in a sense.” The success of Lethal Company is also due to jumpscares. In Twitch live broadcasts, you can often see streamers being scared by spiders that appear from nowhere while doing tasks. In the game Naraka: Bladepoint, we can also see players use the scene to artificially create some “jumpscares” to bring extra game fun: the Tianhai master hidden in the grass gives the unsuspecting Kurumi a little “surprise”.

 

Jumpscare in 《Lethal Company》

I. Research on the Relationship Between Jumpscares and Cognitive Load

Generally speaking, the purpose of horror games is to allow players to experience thrills, and jumpscares achieve this by putting players in a state of physiological arousal: usually under the stimulation of jumpscares, players will experience increased heart rate, sweating, blinking, and heavier breathing. These physiological arousal responses are actually our body ensuring our safety when potential high-risk stimuli (such as gunshots) appear. For example, an increased heart rate is actually to improve our motor ability to avoid danger; blinking is to protect our vital visual organs; and sweating and heavier breathing are side effects of the sympathetic nervous system being upregulated.

One of the key factors influencing physiological arousal is cognitive load. Cognitive load refers to the proportion of the human brain’s information processing system that is occupied. The heavier the cognitive load, the less energy we have left to use.

Based on the influence of cognitive load on physiological arousal, researchers Thomas Terkildsen, Lene Engelst, and Mathias Clasen from Aarhus University in Denmark proposed the hypothesis that “cognitive load is also related to the final effect of jumpscares” and conducted a systematic study on this hypothesis. The researchers decided to simulate different levels of cognitive load through four memory training sessions of different difficulty levels, and to determine whether physiological arousal and psychological arousal were brought out by jumpscares by measuring electrodermal activity graphs and having players self-report their psychological responses.

Experimental Environment: High-Fidelity Graphic Horror Game Developed Using Unity

In order to give the experiment participants an immersive experience, the researchers developed a high-fidelity graphic horror game using the Unity game engine. The researchers believe that developing a new game is necessary because this can ensure that the tasks used later to simulate different levels of cognitive load can be seamlessly integrated into the game and its narrative to maximize the realism of the research.

At the beginning of the game, the player wakes up from a nightmare in a small, dimly lit room. With a loud knock on the metal door, a guard appears and tells the player that it is time for the test. The player is taken out of the room and along a long corridor with cells on both sides. The guard leading the way drags another guard out of the cell, covered in wounds and blood. Eventually, the player reaches the room next to the cell where the injured guard was seen. The layout of the entire room was inspired by a similar scene in the popular horror game A Chair in a Room by Wolf & Wood. There is a blank Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA)* on the table in the room, next to a small plastic container containing two pills. A doctor behind the glass window instructs the player through the intercom to take the pills and sit in the chair in the middle of the room to start the test. The projector on the wall starts to work…

 

Game Scene Described in the Text Above

–.

 

Left: Scene in 《A Chair in a Room》; Right: Scene in the Game Used in the Experiment

* The Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA) was developed by Professor Nasreddine in 2004 and is a rapid screening assessment tool for Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI). The cognitive domains assessed include attention and concentration, executive function, memory, language, visuospatial skills, abstract thinking, and calculation and orientation. The time it takes for a therapist to complete the MoCA assessment is approximately 20 minutes.

Tasks to Simulate Cognitive Load

After guiding the player to the task through the game, the researchers set up four cognitive load intensity environments for 60 players: zero cognitive load, low cognitive load, medium cognitive load, and high cognitive load. During the test, a series of different patterns will be shown to the players, and the players need to remember the position of the blue squares in the patterns. The rounds in which the blue squares to be memorized appear are incremented according to the cognitive load intensity group.

As the task progresses and the intensity increases, the distance between the patterns that the player needs to remember and the current time increases, the difficulty of memory gradually increases, and the player’s cognitive load also gradually increases. The jumpscare suddenly appears in this task: a grinning monster will yell and interrupt the current memory task, rushing to the player.

 

Task to Simulate Cognitive Load

–.

 

Scene of the Jumpscare

Measurement Tools and Experimental Results

In this experiment, the researchers mainly measured the following aspects:

  • Player’s self-reported psychological arousal: Measured using the Self-Assessment Manikin, a graphic-based questionnaire.
  • Objective physiological arousal: Measured by electrodermal activity.
  • Player’s subjective cognitive load intensity: Measured using the NASA Task Load Index questionnaire.
  • Objective cognitive load intensity: Measured by the performance of completing the cognitive load task (accuracy and reaction time to choose the answer).

The experiment showed that the manipulation of cognitive load intensity was effective: both objective reaction time and subjective reports showed that cognitive load was indeed different under the four experimental task conditions. As cognitive load gradually increased in the four experimental conditions, the physiological arousal produced by the jumpscare also increased. This coincides with the hypothesis of the experiment.

It is worth mentioning that the player’s self-reported psychological arousal did not change significantly with the change of cognitive load. The researchers said that this is likely because the reactions caused by jumpscares are difficult to detect through conscious awareness; there are also many other studies in related literature showing that emotional and physiological “stimulation” cannot be accurately captured by people in the form of self-reports.

 

*Experimental Results: Mean and Standard Deviation of Five Indicators: Accuracy, Reaction Time, Self-Reported Cognitive Load, Physiological Arousal, and Self-Reported Psychological Arousal Under Four Experimental Conditions

–.

 

*Experimental Results: As Cognitive Load Increases, Physiological Arousal Also Increases, Indicating That Players Are More Affected by Jumpscares

II. How to Better Apply “Jumpscares” in Game Design

Appropriate Level of Scare

For the game industry, the research by researchers at Aarhus University points out that unpleasant experiences in games can sometimes better allow players to gain pleasure, but it should be noted that when using negative emotions with unpleasant feelings, the scale should be grasped. The relationship between fear and pleasure is usually an inverted U-shape. Only when there is an appropriate amount of horror can the player experience be maximized. Too low or too high horror may be counterproductive.

Some overseas players have expressed problems on forums about the poor experience caused by horror games being too scary; for example, some players on Reddit said that Laura’s part in The Evil Within made them feel very tormented. In the use of jumpscares, the dosage also needs to be controlled. Some games will overuse this technique, which will cause the jumpscares to lose their effect over time; some players also said that the use of jumpscares in Prey is just right, and only one powerful scare is enough to make people remember it.

 

Reddit User Comments

Reasonable Usage Scenarios

In horror games, scaring players unexpectedly by letting them concentrate on puzzles, tasks, and other plots can greatly enhance the experience of horror. Game developers have already unintentionally applied this.

Of the more than 10,000 games under the “Horror” tag on the Steam store, more than 3,000 also have the “Puzzle” element tag. In the new game Content Warning released in 2024, the developers increased the cognitive load by letting players act as photographers in the game plot, enhancing the stimulation of horror scenes.

In horror games, the use of jumpscares is reasonable and natural, but how to use the jumpscare technique in non-horror themed games is relatively vague. In games where players can interact with the environment and other players, jumpscares can actually be used by players. Returning to the action of players hiding in the grass in Naraka: Bladepoint mentioned at the beginning, it is precisely because the creations in the environment can be utilized that players are given room for self-expression and creation. When the cognitive load is high, the effect of this jumpscare will also be enhanced. Just as if a hidden player suddenly appears next to a player who is concentrating on picking up equipment, the effect of the jumpscare will be very strong.

 

In the Game 《Content Warning》, Players Act as Cameramen for Paranormal Event Streamers

Conclusion

The use of jumpscares is very extensive in games. A good jumpscare can make players feel excited and memorable. Researchers at Aarhus University proposed the hypothesis that the level of cognitive load will affect the player’s experience of jumpscares, and verified this hypothesis through a horror game combined with a memory test.

The experimental results show that the higher the cognitive load, the stronger the stimulation felt by the player when experiencing jumpscares. Based on this conclusion, we can more cleverly combine the plot, tasks, or puzzle-solving components in the game with jumpscares to bring players a more interesting game experience.

entry.title: Rejecting Stereotypes: What Kind of Game Characters Can Best Capture Players' Hearts
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

 

Games, as an important social medium, have one of their most important functions: the ability to quickly mobilize people’s emotions in a short period. In many games, one of the most common elements that mobilize players’ emotions is the game character. Because whether it is deeply exploring the plot or experiencing intense battles, the first thing players come into contact with is the character.

So what kind of game character can best capture the player’s heart in the first place? An important point is to enable players to truly immerse themselves in the role and experience the game immersively during the game, that is, to quickly enter a state of flow. The state that people show when they are focused on something is called flow by psychologist Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi. For example, when an artist is creating, when a player is engrossed in a game, their energy is completely invested in it, and at the same time, they have a strong sense of excitement and fulfillment. This is also why we sometimes play a game so “selflessly” that we ignore the passage of time.

When we talk about game characters, there are many ways to express the dimensions that are often mentioned. This article will focus on the visual image, persona, personality and other aspects of the character to explore what kind of game characters can capture the player’s heart and leave a unique and vivid impression.

I. The External Image of the Character

External image usually refers to the character’s shape, appearance, physical attributes, etc. When first getting to know a character, the first thing a player sees is their external image, and whether the player likes the character or not is often initially judged at first sight. Only when there is initial goodwill towards the character will there be an interest in further understanding the character.

For example, during the promotional period before the official launch of the character Ji Yingying in the game Naraka: Bladepoint, even in just 20 seconds of the trailer CG, players couldn’t resist her “smile back”, and almost couldn’t forget her face at first sight. An amazing first impression also laid a good foundation for Ji Yingying’s continued high popularity. After her hero’s actual gameplay demonstration was released, the skill effects based on the Wuchang Lock and Nether Fire also brought players a hearty battle experience, enhancing the sense of satisfaction from multiple senses.

Another example is YORHA No. 2 Type B (2B), one of the protagonists of NieR: Automata. She is the most popular character in the game and the most beautiful character in the hearts of players. Short white hair, blue-grey eyes, wearing a black blindfold (standard military goggles), carrying a silver-white samurai sword behind her, coupled with a black Gothic-style dress, the cool image surprised everyone as soon as it appeared. In addition, she always covers her eyes with a black half-face blindfold, revealing only a little bit of her face, which also casts a mysterious veil over this character. The form of wielding a giant weapon in battle, the agility, and the elegant action design, combined with the setting of a mecha-girl, are even more eye-catching.

II. Character Persona Tags

Giving characters some specific persona tags can enhance the richness and three-dimensionality of the characters and help establish psychological identification with players. This is the core process of closely connecting the player’s heart with the character, and it is also a crucial part of driving the player’s preferences and decision-making and other psychological mechanisms. When a character has prominent traits, it is easy for players to establish a good impression of them.

For example, previously, on the occasion of the 35th anniversary of the Final Fantasy series, the official released a vote, allowing players to choose the best series of games and characters in their minds. Among them, Emet-Selch from Final Fantasy XIV ranked first in the number of votes. One of the reasons why he is so popular with players is his distinctive and contrasting personality.

First of all, when he first appeared, the initial impression he gave players was a puzzling and very indifferent villain image. But with more in-depth contact and understanding later, his completely opposite gentle and careful side will gradually be revealed. Combined with his personal experience: although he is good at conspiracy and has killed many people, his inner obsession is ultimately just to find his relatives and revive his compatriots. This kind of flesh-and-blood, and very contrasting personality makes players love and hate him, and leave a deep impression.

Taking Ji Yingying as an example, in the story background of Naraka: Bladepoint, she is the most outstanding ghost messenger of the Wuchang Division, and she is a daunting existence in Morus Isle. Her hero introduction describes her as, “The infernal fire from the netherworld will burn all those who have betrayed her.” At the same time, her powerful combat ability also aroused the player’s admiration for the strong.

On the other hand, her persona is a “three-no girl”, silent, introverted, and keeping strangers away, which creates a sense of contrast, making players not only imagine that without emotions, it is hard to imagine how strong she would be. Looking at her life background, she was abandoned by her family since she was a child and bears the infernal fire of revenge as Bai Wuchang - players will always remember the character they deeply sympathized with. The persona tags discussed above can effectively evoke and strengthen the player’s emotions.

When a game character goes deep into the player’s mind, the character is established. We found in our research that when players examine their appearance and skins, they will also have a conventional answer based on the character’s image. Players are more concerned about the fit of fashion and characters. Factors such as lines, voice, hero stories, and character relationships that constitute the three-dimensionality of the character’s personality will affect the player’s judgment on whether a piece of fashion is beautiful and coordinated, and whether it has a story, and whether it can stand up to scrutiny.

Therefore, it is very risky to easily change the persona or create points that contradict the original persona. For example, the male character Temulch in Naraka: Bladepoint was set from the beginning of the game as the bloodline of the prairie wolf king. “The legends of the ancestors are engraved in the mind, and the great glory is in front of you. The wolf from the prairie will run wildly again.” When he puts on a gorgeous dress, there are many players who stick to the persona, and they will feel very out of place.

III. The Inner Character of the Character

Inner personality usually refers to the character’s internal tendencies and psychological characteristics, in terms of thinking and behavior towards people, things, and themselves. Just like the popularity of MBTI tests among friends in recent years, some personality tests are popular because they can give people more recognition and a sense of belonging from a psychological point of view. When everyone has their own “personality label”, they can quickly establish and deepen people’s understanding of each other.

People always yearn to understand their own hearts and are obsessed with finding similar souls that resonate with them. In the game, when a character’s internal personality is rich and three-dimensional enough, it also has the importance of conveying emotions. Players’ preferences for the personality traits of game characters also vary from person to person. These characteristics can be confident, humorous, vulnerable, kind, brave; they can be like Astarion in Baldur’s Gate 3, with a complex but unique personality; they can be like Geralt in The Witcher 3: Wild Hunt, a mature and professional witcher, providing players with a deep sense of empowerment and helping them deal with powerful enemies; or you can also fall in love with Tali in Mass Effect 2, and she doesn’t even have a face.

The above are examples of popular game character images with distinct characteristics that are loved by players all over the world. They are unique in the hearts of players and can also resonate strongly with players. At the same time, there are also many characters that are relatively unattractive. We found in player research that players will give feedback such as “no impression”, “not sure what he (in the story) wants to do, what is his goal”, “seems to see the shadow of several existing characters”, etc. for some characters who have a relatively low sense of existence in some games, that is, the characterization is “stereotyped”.

The stereotyped here does not refer to the visual image of the face. After all, many games now support personalized face customization. Players can customize their faces according to their own preferences, or even photos. The character stereotype discussed in this article focuses more on internal personality traits.

For example, in our research on a certain game, based on the data fed back by players, we compared the similarity of personality traits of two male characters and found that the similarity of the two in various dimensions is extremely high. This is also the reason why players are confused and ask “the two are indistinguishable”. If there is no difference in internal personality, it will be difficult to create a memorable character in the subsequent development of the character line.

Conclusion

In many scenarios where we usually contact users, whether it is about art or gameplay, players always tend to focus on characters. By shaping a memorable character, we can better understand the motivation and emotional connection of players to experience the game, and also better understand how to deepen the attraction and psychological identification of players in the game.

The above is a preliminary exploration of character shaping in game design. In addition, the character’s special skills, dubbing, etc. are also sufficient manifestations to help shape its three-dimensional image and identity. Of course, when talking about a certain character, we are definitely not looking at it from a single dimension. Only by fully considering many factors such as the character’s appearance, background, personality, and setting can we create a distinctive and beloved character.

entry.title: Help! Why is This Boss Music Stuck in My Head!
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

 

In Justice Online Mobile’s previously released Mirror Pavilion dungeon, the music for one of the outer pavilion bosses, Nan Wenxue, left a particularly deep impression on players. It was able to effectively mobilize players’ emotions, making them feel the poignancy and murderous intent from Nan Wenxue, creating a strong sense of immersion.

This sparked thought: why do we have such a strong memory of some music? And how can this phenomenon be explained from a psychological perspective?

Comments on the NetEase Cloud Music page for “You Mei Xiao Gu” (Withered Plum Bone), the boss music for Mirror Pavilion’s Nan Wenxue are positive, and refer to it’s quality.

I. How Attention and Memory Work

Before further explaining this phenomenon through examples, we need to first understand how the human brain’s attention and memory work.

Memory

When receiving external information, this information first enters sensory memory, then enters short-term memory, and then enters long-term memory after a series of encodings.

Sensory memory usually refers to memory of about 1 second. Here, the brain will quickly perceive a large amount of information from the outside world, but at the same time, most of the information will also disappear quickly. Only the information that is noticed will enter short-term memory.

If we were to use a computer’s working mode as an analogy, short-term memory can be compared to cache. It passively stores the audio-visual information we hear and see, although it allows us to quickly retrieve memories. It cannot store a large amount of content at one time, and its capacity is relatively small.

Long-term memory is RAM. Comparatively, it can store more content and has a larger capacity, but it requires us to deliberately and actively save information, and the process of saving information is relatively time-consuming.

Attention

Everyone’s brain has a certain amount of “cognitive resources”, and exceeding the limit will cause “cognitive load.” In the case of a large amount of information constantly stimulating the brain every minute and every second, how does the brain process this information to avoid cognitive load?

The answer is through “attention.” Attention has the following characteristics:

  • Selectivity: The brain will selectively attend to some information while ignoring other information.
  • Concentration: The brain will eliminate irrelevant stimuli to ensure that information is concentrated.
  • Persistence: The brain’s operation is linear, so “attention”, which is very important in the process of filtering information, also needs to remain stable for a certain period.
  • Distribution: Often, we are not fully invested in a single event. When doing two or more things at the same time, it will involve the allocation of attention.

It was mentioned above that the brain will eliminate irrelevant information stimuli, so how does the brain reduce interference?

The human brain has an area specifically responsible for suppressing irrelevant interference input. When the auditory area and the visual area are triggered at the same time, the prefrontal cortex will selectively inhibit the relatively less important area according to the importance of the information. By suppressing the information flow of the unimportant area, the information flow of another area will become relatively more prominent.

II. How Does the Brain Remember Music? And How Does it Retrieve Musical Memories?

After understanding how the brain works in attention and memory, let’s look at how the brain remembers music.

When playing games and listening to some game music with specific tonality, we use short-term memory more, in which “short-term musical memory” plays a key role.

What the brain remembers is not a complete melody, but the harmonic structure carried by the melody. In the previous article, “How Games Control Your Emotions Through Music,” it was mentioned that harmony will determine the emotional color of the melody to a certain extent. Whether it is happy or sad, excited or relaxed, and harmonic progression will constitute the development direction of the music, whether it is moving towards the climax or coming to the end.

Therefore, our brain will remember this harmonic context, and will further understand the melody heard based on this harmonic context.

In the process of remembering music with only one tonality, it is normal to have a few unclear memories. Switching to the scene of recalling and retrieving musical memories, the brain will try to fill in this note in the process of outlining the melody. The logic of filling in is based on the melody contour, and a relatively close alternative note is located from the tonality constituted by the harmonic context to fill in this vacancy.

III. Battle and Exploration, What are Players Listening to and Remembering?

In our previous research, we found that in most cases, players tend to not care about the specific details of the battle music, but just “listen to a sound”, or more accurately, listen to the “emotional atmosphere.”

So, why is there this phenomenon?

During battle, there will be many changes in vision, such as the attack direction of the big boss and the operations of teammates. At the same time, hearing will also continue to transmit various battle information, scene information, and so on. Under the bombardment of a large amount of information, in order to avoid cognitive load, the brain will allocate cognitive resources from top to bottom, choosing to focus attention on the more important battle and ignoring other information, so as to better adjust battle strategies based on information changes.

Zooming in on the brain’s operation, at this time, the prefrontal cortex will inhibit part of the auditory information flow, so that the visual information flow is more obvious and easier to remember.

At the level of conscious awareness, auditory attention is more biased towards listening to the content of teammates opening the microphone, and at the same time, background music will be ignored, because it is necessary to cooperate with teammates. But this does not mean that the background music is useless. At this time, the role of the background music is more biased towards the subconscious level, mainly acting on the arousal of emotions, making people feel the passionate atmosphere of the battle.

This leads to another question, why do some people feel that playing music while playing games interferes with their strategic thinking, while others feel more passionate and immersive?

In fact, everyone’s cognitive resources are different, some are high and some are low, and there are individual differences. Among them, people with larger cognitive resource capacity can process more information at the same time. At the same time, everyone’s focus on information is also different. People who care about the sense of immersion brought by game music will be more easily immersed in the emotional atmosphere created by the music, while people who don’t care may feel that the music interferes with their thinking.

But no matter which group of people, everyone’s primary memory is the emotional atmosphere brought by the music, not the details of the music. Generally speaking, without prompts, players cannot directly recall what the battle music is like.

Justice Online Mobile has corresponding city music for different cities. Some will change with the day and night and the weather, so that you can be immersed in it when exploring or running around.

Unlike battles, when exploring and running around, cognitive resources are no longer highly concentrated on a certain matter, players are more open to information, and their attention will also be more dispersed. At this time, they can pay attention to some small designs, whether it is scene sound effects such as birdsong, water flow, or background music. This is also why players are more likely to recall exploration music with distinct melodic characteristics.

IV. Why Can Some Boss Music Be Remembered?

Returning to the original question, why can the music of Justice Online Mobile’s boss Nan Wenxue be remembered?

Vocal Theme-Based Main Melody

In this boss music, the production team incorporated vocal design. This means that when players listen to this piece of music, in addition to the music information, there is actually text information, and the brain will also process the lyrics in an additional layer. This makes the human voice stand out among a bunch of instruments. This strong contrast effect will also make it easier for players to notice the human voice, and then notice the music.

The south branch is withered, the wind holds the snow and turns, don’t let it fall. The fragrance disappears, the plum blossoms scatter, and the floating life follows the flowing water. - Lyrics of “You Mei Xiao Gu”

Coordination with Gameplay Mechanics

As mentioned in the previous article, the effect of music and gameplay is often 1+1>2. On the basis of excellent gameplay mechanism design, Nan Wenxue’s vocal singing coordinates well with the gameplay. It roughly appears shortly before and after the appearance of the Peach Blossom Girl, setting off the atmosphere and making players feel the “killing intent” from the boss.

Why is it effective at this node? This is because here, except for individual players who need to focus on the position of the boss, most of the others are in a state of pure fighting without needing to think too much about battle and positioning strategies. Players’ cognitive resources still have a lot of spare capacity at this node to notice corresponding design details.

Repetitive Stimulation

The Mirror Pavilion·Outer Pavilion’s Nan Wenxue, the dungeon boss, is both an interesting and challenging dungeon boss in this raid. Because there is a certain degree of difficulty, and the dungeon is an important channel for equipment upgrades, players will continue to participate in this dungeon. The impressive female vocal singing of “You Mei Xiao Gu” is also set in the boss stage that players will experience. This means that players will generally experience this piece of music once every time they participate in this dungeon. Like the learning process, this repeated emphasis and stimulation can deepen the brain’s memory of the music segment, thereby making the music more likely to enter long-term memory, making people have an impression and remember it.

Conclusion

In short, understanding the player’s attention and memory patterns, including the neural operation process of the brain, can assist the development team in designing details in the game that better meet the needs of the experience. In the process of designing music, it is also necessary to linearly and structurally understand the process and rhythm of the entire gameplay. Doing the right design at the right node can achieve better results.

entry.title: Why Do Players Turn a Blind Eye? Novice Guide Design from the Perspective of Attention Mechanisms
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

 

When players experience a new game or new gameplay, they often complain that the game’s guidance is unclear and they don’t understand how to play. On the other hand, game designers feel very confused. The game clearly has a large section of gameplay introduction, so why do players feel that the guidance is not enough?

Why do players always “turn a blind eye” to the carefully prepared novice guides by developers? Do they really not see it, or do they not want to see it? In a previous article, we mainly analyzed what kind of information is easier to be seen from the perspective of involuntary attention.

First, let’s do a brief review.

What is attention? -> If the human brain is a TV, external information is various TV programs, and attention is the process of selecting TV programs. What is involuntary attention? -> Those that do not require willful effort and can be naturally noticed by people. For example, a ringing mobile phone in a quiet conference room is hard not to be heard.

What information is easier to attract involuntary attention, that is, easier for players to see (pay attention to)?

  • The characteristics of the information itself are different and differentiated. Such as novel stimuli (more pictures than words, more words than pictures), stimuli with higher relative intensity (such as darkening for emphasis), and motion changes (such as dynamic effects).
  • The information fits the person’s own state, interests, and needs. For example, when a new player encounters a brand-new function that needs to be used immediately, he will have a clear need for the novice tutorial. At this time, the pop-up guide will be more easily noticed.

Based on the characteristics of attention, the inspiration for novice guide design is as follows:

  • Contrast effect 1: More pictures, look at words; more words, look at pictures; highlight the differences.
  • Contrast effect 2: Less is more; the more blank space, the easier it is to be seen.
  • Multi-channel presentation: Visual + auditory multi-sensory presentation.
  • Proximity effect: The closer the picture and text are, the better the learning (any form of prompt clues can guide players to pay attention to the key points faster).
  • People’s eyes tend to follow arrows, and hand-drawn arrow prompts can be used to highlight key points.

So in the actual novice guide design, if the planner makes it according to the above standards, can it be ensured that the player can see it? Not necessarily. Specific problems still need specific analysis. In this article, we will present several conclusions that are different from the previous sharing, and will still explain why this happens from the perspective of attention.

I. Is it Really “Text is Inferior to Tables, Tables are Inferior to Pictures, and Pictures are Inferior to Videos”?

Let’s start with a non-prize quiz. In the following guidance screen about Parry in Naraka: Bladepoint, where do you think the player’s visual focus will be.

There will mainly be 3 answers to this experiment. One answer is on the character, one answer is on the restraint relationship diagram in the upper left corner, and a few answers are on the controller diagram in the lower right corner.

But unfortunately, none of the above answers are correct. The eye-tracking test results show an answer that surprises everyone. Players only saw the animation at the beginning, and then focused on the text below, and did not watch the animation demonstration again. And this is not just an individual case of one player. In the test of 10 players, 7-8 similar guide video contents in the game guide, the player’s focus is not on the video, but on the text.

Why does this happen? Generally, we will think that vivid and visual pictures and personally demonstrated videos will be more focused on by players, and they will have more patience to watch them than boring text introductions, helping players learn some complex operations.

Here we need to introduce another type of attention - “voluntary attention”. In contrast to “involuntary attention”, “voluntary attention” is a conscious act of paying attention that requires willful effort. When we need to learn complex knowledge, we need the real “top student” type of “voluntary attention” to play.

As the eye-tracking data shows, at the beginning of the video, the player’s attention is attracted by the animation. At this time, “involuntary attention” is playing a role, which is in line with the principle that the higher the stimulus intensity, the more attention it attracts. But soon, the player finds that he can’t understand this animation. At this time, voluntary attention comes into play. For voluntary attention, familiarity is an important influencing factor. The more familiar things are, the faster the processing starts, and the easier it is to attract people’s attention at this time. Compared with the animation that cannot be understood, Chinese characters are still more familiar, so the brain is more inclined to process the text below, which is more helpful for understanding this guide.

For the same guide, if it is shown to players who are already familiar with Naraka: Bladepoint, their focus will be more on the video, because they are familiar with the various elements in the video and can quickly understand the information conveyed by the video interpretation. But for new players, the attack moves, blue light, and white light elements in the video are all unfamiliar, let alone understanding the relationship between them through interpretation.

Under the same conditions, the information transmission effect of video is better than that of text, and it is more able to capture attention. This is beyond doubt. This is also a place where it is easier to fall into the trap. Believing in the video theory transmission effect of video pictures, but ignoring the understandability of video pictures, will make players turn to complex text guidance with a low ceiling but a lower threshold.

It is also difficult for designers to find that players have this unexpected behavior through their own tests, because the familiarity of planners and players with this video is completely different. Combining the characteristics of voluntary attention, in this guide video, if the presentation of key elements or relationships can be matched with brief text descriptions that players are more “familiar” with, it can better capture the player’s attention and also help understanding.

II. No Matter What You Put, I Can’t See It?

Does this desperate situation really exist? Yes, it does. Are players really so reluctant to read guides? No, sometimes they really don’t see them.

In the attention processing mechanism, we have a theory called the cognitive resource theory. This theory regards “attention” as a set of cognitive resources or cognitive abilities to classify and identify stimuli. These cognitive resources are limited. When the stimulus is more complex or the processing task is more complex, the more cognitive resources are occupied. When cognitive resources are fully occupied, new stimuli will not be processed. This is what we call the state of “turning a deaf ear to the outside world and concentrating on reading only the books of sages”.

At this time, it is easier for us to understand why the eye-tracking trajectory diagram of the following novice guide appears like this.

From this picture, we can also find that the player’s focus is completely concentrated on the surrounding scene, that is, the things that are highly related to the current task. They are focusing on performing the task at hand, so they turn a deaf ear to such obvious guidance prompts above. In the actual test, most of the players also stated that they did not see the prompt text above.

But for us who are looking at such pictures, because we don’t need to consider the tasks that the player is currently performing, the attention processing resources are not occupied. The guide text above, “Double-click the A+D keys to roll in the specified direction and avoid the slash”, is very easy to attract our attention, and almost no one will not see it.

The more cognitive resources are occupied, the more concentrated the attention, and the smaller the scope of attention. In tasks that require identifying the details of things, the human field of vision is only about 1-2 degrees. This size is about the size of your thumbnail when you hold your arm parallel. When we get information, we don’t look at ten lines at a glance, but our eyeballs are constantly turning and shifting the point of gaze.

When the eyeball is stationary, the human visual coverage is about 220 degrees. But when you need to identify the details of things, such as reading text or recognizing a logo, you need to continuously rotate your eyeballs to project the position you want to know to the fovea of the retina (Fovea - a small depression in the center of the retina cone cells, that is, the macula, which can perceive the richest image details). This is also the principle of the eye tracker. The eye tracking system is mainly capturing the gaze points and the transfer behavior between gaze points.

In response to this situation, a common practice is to place auxiliary information as much as possible within the range of concentrated attention. For example, the head-up display of a car. When driving, the attention is mainly focused on observing the road conditions, and the gaze range is mainly concentrated in the windshield range. The information on the traditional car dashboard is relatively difficult to be noticed during driving. Therefore, some new cars try to display driving assistance information on the windshield.

In games, some better practices are to put the guide on the task-related gaze path, or next to the character or weapon that the player gazes at more, which can ensure that the prompt information can be noticed more effectively. For example, Naraka: Bladepoint places button prompts on the target scene; God of War displays some operation guides next to the axe.

III. The Scope of Attention is So Small, Do All Guidance Information Need to be Stacked Near the Character?

From the above several cases, we understand that when players concentrate on performing game tasks, the scope of attention is very small. The gaze point is mostly distributed near the task-related path and the character. So do all prompt information need to be stacked near the character? Not necessarily.

Here we need to introduce another attention processing theory, the dual processing theory of attention: human cognitive processing has two types: automatic processing and conscious controlled processing. The former is not limited by cognitive resources, does not require attention, and can be carried out automatically; the latter is limited by cognitive resources, requires attention, and can be continuously adjusted according to changes in the environment. That is, when performing multiple activities at the same time, one or more of them have become automated processes, and individuals no longer need to consume cognitive resources, and they can concentrate their attention on other cognitive processes. Consciously controlled processing may be transformed into automatic processing after a lot of practice.

Therefore, although our processing resources are limited, if we can automatically process more information, we can cover more and more comprehensive information. Experience can transform the content of voluntary attention into automatic processing, which does not occupy cognitive resources, so that more information can be processed.

In games, the most obvious manifestation is the difference in the gaze range between veterans and novices. As can be seen from the figure below, the visual range of both new and veteran players is centered on themselves. However, the visual attention range of veteran players is larger, accounting for more than 1/3 of the whole; the visual attention range of novice players is smaller, about 1/4 of the whole.

Veterans can achieve a good degree of automatic identification of tasks such as character movement and combat, so they have more attention resources to notice other information prompts that appear on the interface, and can also gaze at a larger range of interface information to complete tasks when needed, such as the skill bar at the bottom.

This attention processing feature has many inspirations for developers. First of all, for the design of novice guidance prompts, the position of guidance prompts does need to be combined with the characteristics of novice gaze range, and as close to the character itself as possible. Secondly, the interface display information is gradually unfolded step by step, so that players can adapt first, become proficient in a basic content, so that they can gradually enter automatic processing, and then enter the next. By gradually transforming the information processing process of some basic tasks into automatic processing, the amount of information that novice players can process at the same time is gradually expanded.

Conclusion

Finally, let’s make a review:

  1. Text is not necessarily inferior to pictures, because in real information processing tasks, voluntary attention mainly plays a role, and familiarity is an important influencing factor. Users tend to process familiar information sources that are more conducive to information processing. Therefore, if the video format is used for guidance, the understandability of the video content presentation is very important.
  2. When performing real tasks, the gaze range is very limited, and the gaze range is strongly related to task-related elements, such as being more concentrated near the character and task path. Therefore, some important information that needs to be noticed by the player can be displayed in these areas.
  3. The information processing range of novices is very limited. First, the position of guidance prompts needs to be combined with the characteristics of novice gaze range, and as close to the character itself as possible. At the same time, it is necessary to gradually display information, so that players can gradually process automatically and expand the range of information that can be processed at the same time.

In general, in the novice guide design, it is also necessary to consider the player’s own information familiarity and the characteristics of attention in actual task execution. It is not possible to simply rely on common image display rules, and specific analysis should be made for specific situations.

entry.title: How Can Game Plots Better Elicit Player Empathy
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

 

Everyone suffers, and no one readily accepts tragedy. In today’s era, people are tired of and even disgusted by consistently happy endings in stories, while also complaining about “knife-inflicting” (creating sad, regretful scenes) plots in entertainment content. Especially in games, which are meant for entertainment, the inclusion of one heartbreaking scene after another often sparks heated discussions among players.

When players immerse themselves in the game world, savoring the scenes created and the stories written by the developers, they generally ask: Do developers have to “stab” players a few times in the process to get their kicks? When “stabbed” (seeing heartbreaking scenes), it often triggers strong emotional reactions in players. Why do developers choose to deliver endless “knives” despite the potential backlash?

I. Emotional Establishment Within the Game

The plot in a game has always been responsible for creating a sense of immersion for the player.

Game characters are, after all, virtual. So how do you make players emotionally resonate with them and fully remember them? The emotional ups and downs and character settings brought about by the plot are particularly critical. The establishment of player emotions requires a fluctuating process. They may forget the lines a character once said, but they will definitely find it difficult to forget the scenes that can bring them intense emotional fluctuations. Therefore, developers sometimes choose to create many sad scenes in the plot to promote the development of the plot, arouse changes in player emotions, and further portray the characters.

Like Haurchefant in Final Fantasy XIV, from an insignificant stranger at the beginning, to gradually forming a connection, and finally being killed by a sneak attack. Thinking of the shelter he once provided, the two cups of hot drinks he held, covering the player’s retreat at the Skyfire Locks, standing up for the player in the trial duel, and even personally training a Chocobo for the player, any user would find it difficult to forget this guy who always calls you “my friend.”

There is a Zeigarnik effect in psychology, which refers to the fact that people tend to remember unfinished things or interrupted work, and there is an inherent concept of having a beginning and an end in human nature, so they will be obsessed with things that have no results. When players do not see the content they expect, they will also remember it deeply. When the visual presentation and gameplay do not have much room to stimulate, players will be distressed by the tragic fate of the characters in the plot, thereby mobilizing emotions, and naturally they can remember this feeling, and thus remember this character and this plot, and even like these characters. Perhaps only a deep “feeling of being stabbed” can indicate that the plot has truly touched the player’s heart.

II. Can’t We Have “Sweetness”?

So why must it be sadness and regret? Can’t “sweetness” (designing many beautiful scenes and bridges) trigger emotional fluctuations in players?

Perceived control in psychology believes that people believe that they can control themselves and the places, people, objects, emotions, and activities around them. When facing a stranger, if he is doing well, the emotion we first produce is to compare. When you feel that you can’t be as good as the other person, you will have a lower sense of control, and it is easier to develop an inferiority complex, which in turn leads to jealousy or other bad emotions. On the contrary, if this person has gone through hardships and has a bumpy fate, what is more generated is sympathy, and further, a feeling of compassion.

From the perspective of the game plot alone, if a plot “has no knives”, the character has no changes, and everything is very good and smooth, the player may instead feel disgusted, unreal, and even more serious boredom. In games, NPCs and characters who are plain or live a happy life are often not remembered by us, and are more like passers-by.

Tragedy is always easier to touch people’s hearts and resonate with than comedy; that’s why it’s always said that the core of comedy is tragedy, otherwise how can a simple comedy move the audience, let alone make people talk about it with relish afterwards.

III. Immersion and Mental Anchors

Immersion: Interweaving Positive and Negative Emotions

Developers often say that they want to give players a sense of immersion, using visuals and plots to instill emotions into the player’s mind. Immersion is a very mysterious concept. During the game experience, players have positive and negative emotional fluctuations. When positive emotions are dominant, they will experience a focused pleasure and have the motivation to invest in it, entering a state of enjoyment. For example, when a player finishes a plot in the game or passes a relatively difficult level, they burst out with a positive emotional catharsis, and thus experience a sense of accomplishment.

However, games are often not all about positive emotions. It is necessary to allow players to have a certain degree of negative emotional fluctuations to avoid fatigue and boredom caused by long-term positive feelings. If negative emotions are created through game mechanics and difficulty, it is easy to cause imbalance, leading to direct churn and discouragement. Developers usually adopt more gentle, more widely accepted tragic plots to achieve this.

Mental Anchor: The Player’s Emotional Switch

Mental anchor is a form of conditioned reflex, which refers to “the connection between a certain mood in a person’s heart and a certain action or expression, resulting in a conditioned reflex”. In short, it’s like a switch. When we see this thing, we will have different moods associated with it. We can call such things that can stimulate special feelings, whether good or bad, mental anchors. It’s like a bookmark placed in the heart, which can be used when needed, and the psychological state at the time of setting the mental anchor can be retrieved. Therefore, a mental anchor is more like a “re-experiencing”.

And in games, similar to gameplay types, when we mention a type, we will think of its representative work; in the plot, when we see a flag, we will think of a tragic ending. Just as assassination and parkour gameplay will remind us of Assassin’s Creed, Cthulhu investigators will easily remind us of Bloodborne, and when we see several corpses and last words in a shelter in The Last of Us, we will naturally depict in our minds a story of a poor person who had to kill a child to prevent the child from becoming a zombie. The game provides classic elements, combines them with various elements in the scene and level, and activates the mental anchors in the player’s mind through scene scheduling, creating an illusion of the plot in the player’s mind.

How to Build a Mental Anchor

When enough immersion and positive emotions are created in the early stage, and the emotional fluctuations are large enough, a positive mental anchor is buried. The player has positive expectations for the plot and creates their own fantasy of the plot. Or it may further arouse the player’s curiosity, resulting in the idea of “there must be a pit buried here, I must play it to find out, to see if it is the same as I thought”. In the later stage, when “handing out knives” to design heartbreaking scenes, players will also perceive something wrong because of other memories before, activating the mental anchor, and “Run, there are knives here” is the most intuitive feeling.

The strong contrast and the conflict between mental anchors cause strong emotional fluctuations in players. Grasping this emotional change of the player, it makes the player have a deep memory point for this plot and this character. This buries the next mental anchor, so that the next time the player encounters an emotional switch, they will have a sense of déjà vu: “Hey, have I experienced this before?”.

Perhaps the interesting plot is never in the game, but in the player’s mind.

Conclusion

In the final analysis, designing “knives” such as tragic plots is just a tool. With a good knife, the characters will be vividly portrayed, the plot conflicts will also be vividly depicted, and the player’s heart will also be “stabbed” severely. After all, although heartbreaking scenes are bitter, they are indispensable. If the “knife” is not given properly, it is just to stimulate the player’s emotions by “tearing up the canvas”, which is more like simply spreading unreasonable negative emotions, with a mentality of “Didn’t expect it, look how bitter it is”, and most players may not buy it. A person who can’t draw a circle with a pen and casually draws an abstract painting will not become a master of art.

The essence of the game is still to be happy, right?

entry.title: The Secret of Open World Map Design: Multi-dimensional Application of Icons
entry.content:
Machine Translated from Chinese to English
Original article written by ThunderFire UX (NetEase)

 

I. Task List: What Icons Need to be Designed for the Map System?

Unlike traditional paper maps, the icon design in the game map interface needs to include various forms of content other than geographical location information. The following list basically encompasses all icons that may appear in an open-world map interface.

  • Regular locations: Mark locations in the game world that players can explore.
  • Character/Important item locations: Indicate the current location or direction of characters or important items.
  • Fast Travel points: Allow players to teleport directly from their current location to the indicated location.
  • Reminder markers: Alert players to unfinished tasks or unclaimed items.
  • User-defined markers: In some games, players can choose an icon provided by the map system to mark a specific location.
  • Direction indicators: Crucial in vast environments; some maps have compass-like icons.
  • Crosshair and cursor: Tools for selecting locations, commonly used in maps navigated with a controller or keyboard.
  • External map information: Provides details such as longitude and latitude, weather, and time.

II. Prerequisite for Ensuring Immersive Experience: How to Improve Icon Usability?

Virtual game environments, similar to real-world scenes, interact with people through various “touch points”.
